Some alcohol in the nose. Pumpkin turned into fruity acidity. Mustiness. Sweetened vegetable broth, but balanced broth. ¿Que?

22/IV/13 - 50cl bottle @ Rampkrot (Deurne) - brewed: 18/X/12 - BB: 18/X/16 - batch: 875 (2013-362) Thanks to Clubgonzo & Inbreak for sharing the bottle! 
Little cloudy red orange beer, small beige head, unstable, bit adhesive. Aroma: funky, lots of spices, cloves, aniseed, yeasty, nutmeg impressions. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: very spicy, caramel, bitter hops, lots of spices, bit bready. Aftertaste: spicy, lots of spices, cloves, aniseed, bit sourish, caramel, overripe fruits. Its ok, I guess.

50cl bottle courtesy of ClubGonzo & Inbreak @ Post Toer de Geuze tasting. Fresh. BB 18-10-2016
Orangée-cuivrée, col fin beige.
Arôme présente ce bouquet sympa dépice de saison, malt-caramel suivi dun léger malté caramel.
Palais est malté avec ce palais épices rappelant le gingerbread-pain dépices et baies de genévrier. Lajout noisette ajoute une certaine complexité et note terreuse de farine de noisette qui se mélange au malté. Palais est épais, caramel avec ce profil épice qui reste en fin de bouche.

Thx to ClubGonzo & Inbreak. 50 cl. bottle sampled. Bottle on 19//10/2012. Dark, light brown amber, little to no white head. Nose is mint, light medicinal, maybe vegetable / pumpkin, bitter medicinal herbs, Taste is caramel, toffee, light herbs, minty, light burned, light medicinal, light cough syrup, sweet liquorish, burned sugar, Lightly fizzy carb. Quite odd and not what expected.

Bottle. Pours darkest brown with tan head. Sage, cola, toffee amd molasses aroma. Taste of toffee, treacle, mollasses, spices and sage. Thick and sweet. Bit of an odd sage and cola party. Cant say I dig this.

500ml bottle. Pours an opaque deep chestnut, with a small beige head, which lasts reasonably well, but does not leave that much lacing. There is a pronounced gin-like aroma, mingled with roasted chestnuts, carraway and the faintest hint of rye bread malt. Sage is the initial flavour, with some peppery hops coming in. A touch of carraway and strong juniper lead into a blend of chestnut and roasty malt in the mid-palate. More juniper, chestnuts and bittersweet chocolate malt create the finish, and there is a gin aftertaste. This is definitely one of the stranger beers I have had for a while. Bizarrely it all works fairly well, despite its odd range of ingredients. The sage and carraway complement the hops, and the chestnuts work brilliantly with the dark, bittersweet malt flavours. The juniper is, however, a little too strong; it dominates proceedings a little. On the whole, though, this is a weird but enjoyable beer.

Bit of a gusher when opened, but didnt lose much and doesnt seem infected.
Aroma is very interesting, like candied lemons and peaches or something. Flavor is fruity in front and spicy with black licorice in back. Super delicious strong porter or stout or something. Fairly heavy creamy body, nuts and sage in finish. Chocolate, fruit, berries, herbs, nuts.

Bottle at Eulogy. Appears to be the 2nd batch (Nogne O with the 3 wisemen on the label.) Very dark copper pour with a slight foamy head. Dark chewy roasted chestnuts. Notably floral with the white sage. Thick red plums. Dates. Celery seed. Vegemite. Black pepper. Cinnamon. Juniper berries. Rotted sweet apples (in a good way.) Those chestnuts still stand out. Just a bit sour but mostly dark and sweet. Nice juicy medium-full palate. Quite interesting. Bit of a rich chewy meal, but well worth having. Please have at room temperature!
This review is exported from olutopas.info with no comment. Original rating date  5.11.2010

Bottle. Deep brown/mohogany body. Huge, fizzy beige head, mostly lasting. Aroma of spice and funkiness  licorice, herbs, cinnamon, all spice, nutmeg, earthiness. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. The beer is complex, but without cohesiveness, as if someone threw a potpourri of spices and sugar into water. Overly sweet and the sweetness lingers well into the finish.
bottle. Brown with small head. Definitely on the medicinal side. Chestnuts are a bit odd, but it almost works. More interesting than good.

0,5L bottle.  Three Kings label (symbolic?).   Aroma of cola.  Not just any cola, specifically RED BULL COLA.  If you have yet to try Red Bull Cola, you should.  Citrus acidity; lime peel, orange peel, lemon peel.  Sage and mustard seed.  Sweet toasted malts; toffees and caramelized sugars.  Wooded chestnuts and whole clove.  All this just in the nose of this beer.  
Tastes of toasted cereal, chestnuts.  Finishes with flavors of  fresh herbal sage, and a sharp bitter pine character.  Dark malts add to the dark brown color.  Rich light tan cream on top adds to the appearance.  Heavy bodied,  overly full of flavor makes this a very complex beer.  Loads of spice.  The tastes of the  Spice/Herb/Vegetable addition linger on the palate for a very long time.  This beer is better than Christmas itself.  

(3630)

Christmas beer as it should be. Noes is traditional christmas spices, but also includes juniper berries, chestnuts and sage. Collabration between Nøgne Ø, jolly pumpkin and Stone makes it truly uniqe. Only downside, itss made in small batches, and not widely distributed.

Nice and different. Malty spice aroma. There was a lot going on. Dark and chocolate colored, almost like a coffee drink.  Small head. The palate was remarkable. Very heavy and thick. Creamy and syrupy. However, it didnt feel heavy in my stomach. The taste was definitely malty with not a whole lot of Stones typical hoppiness. Spices, even some pumpkin and burnt bread. It took a while to process. Kudos for its uniqueness.

Bottle at home with friends, courtesy of André. Thanks man! Pour is murky brown with a slight red tint and small cream head. Huge herbal/medicinal aroma, definitely full of juniper,  pumpkin, nutmeg, and a touch of caramel in the aroma. Taste is caramelly, medicinal, herbal, juniper, pine, bread, and licorice with a lightly spicy finish. Light body with soft carbonation. Not bad.

Pour out of 500 mL bottle, dark reddish pour with thin white head, aroma brought notes of juniper, mint, toffee, hints of earth, grain, slight spice.  Taste is a mix of juniper, toffee, caramel, slight grain, spice, slight pumpkin, finishing fairly sweet.
Draft at blue monk. Darker pour. Sweet malts, purple grapes, sweet cherry notes. Floral notes, juniper gin like florals. Chocolate malts. Pretty flavorful, bi mouthfeel, good beer
Poured from a 500ml bottle, thanks Santa. Spicy, malty, earthy, fruity/berries,hot alcohol, caramel, cocoa. A great holiday ale.

16.9oz bottle. Dark deep ruby red / black color. Thin brown head. Dots of lace. Bigger body. Very smooth texture, kind of creamy, lighter smooth carbonation. Very interesting and tasty. Spice, cinnamon, and dark fruit flavor. Nice herbal hop flavor. Little roasty malts. Sweeter taste, but a good amount of bitter, too. Alcohol isnt too noticeable for me. Lots of fine sediment visible in the body. Some orange. Pleasant caramel malt. Delicious stuff. Very tasty and impressively easy to drink.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with little head. Nose is all spice, lots of sage and nutmeg, maybe some juniper. Taste is also all spice, so much sage with some clove and maybe caramel. Certainly not my kind of beer.

OMG ! One of my favorite beer ! Very very great strong taste of caramel ! Good enough hops, if u want to compare this beer with others , you probably shouldnt ! Comes to Norway (Oslo) once or twice a year !
Draft: Nutmeg, clove, cardamom, cranberry, vinous nose. Hazy maroon, thin yellow head, good lacing. Cranberry, leather, and clove flavor. Full body, velvety. A bit perfumey. Good.
Pours dark amber, no head.  Smells nutty and like caramel.  Very spicy and creamy.  Caramel, vanilla, nutmeg, chestnuts, and cream.

Viime joulusta asti kypsytelty tapaus kaatuu lasiin tummana, lähes mustana ja rusehtavalla vaahdolla, joka kuitenkin katosi suht nopeaan. Haju on julmystmainen, hyvin jouluinen, piparinen, kuivattua sitrushedelmää ja vielä luumuakin. Maku on lakritsinen, piparinen, hieman eukalyptuksinen, paahteinen ja jotain trooppista hedelmääkin löytyy nopeasti. Suutuntuma on täyteläinen, mutta hieman liian hyökkäävä. Kokonaisuutena todella monimuotoinen ja täyteläinen jouluun sopiva olut, jolle kypsyttely on tehnyt hyvää (tuoreena maistui jotenkin keskeneräiselle). Nögne ei ole vielä pettänyt.

Pours a deep mahogany color with a half finger of eggshell foam that stocks and sings out nicely. On the nose its subtle with touches of warm herbal spice, toasted malts and earthy yeast. The palate is soft and balanced with great complex flavor profile hitting all the special ingredients evenly... a soft caramel background  provides a great base for the juniper, sage and herbal  cola notes to shine without overpowering. Great mouthfeel and smoothness that mimics velvet. Nice lingering woodsy notes on the finish.

Bottle shared by Dallas 
Appearance: Clear amber with a small tan head and good lacing 
Aroma: Holiday spices, berries and sage 
Taste: Holiday spices, bready with a dry finish 
Decent

500ml bottle brewed 2010 (shared by FatPhil, thanks). Dark brown, almost black color. Raisins, woody, cinnamon and faint ginger in aroma. Nice roast, malty, spicy, sense of aging in flavor. Milky texture. Another one please!

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2013 Light brown, clear, beige head. Aroma: bready malt with some leather, dried dark fruit, sage is evident, subtle juniper. Flavor of dark bread (pumpernickel, caraway), toffee, nutty notes, sage, juniper, berry-like fruitiness, all in good proportion. Very well done. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Deep brown pour with a thunbs worth of white/light brown head.  Holiday spices in the aroma - Nutmeg, Juniper, Spicy red wine, brown sugar.  juniper and Molasses was the first thing I though when I tasted, but as it warmed the molasses taste was replaced with brown sugar and black liquorice.  Nutmeg, ripe fruit, evergreen, some cinnamon in the background.  The chesnut also came out as this warmed.   Medium body.  Give it time to warm up - I went from being not quite impressed to appreciating the complexity of this one as it warmed.

Bottle at pub, Bergen. Seems clear and has a deep brown colour with a small light beige head. Lots of Christmas spices in the aroma along with cardamom, heather, Christmas cakes, dark berries, hot wine and some roasted malt and anis. More leather in the flavour with pine, oak and dark berries. Has a soft and oily mouthfeel, and a light bitterness. A real Christmas ale. Well spiced and nice.

50 cl bottle @ lusikka. Batch #526, brewed 03.08.2010, BBE 03.08.2015
Vertical with Stones version, this one was more spicy and better. 
Aroma is rather spicy with pepper, some herbs and juniper. Also Nøgne house aroma is present. Flavour has peppery spices, juniper and nice licorice aroma.

Skarp, men forskjellig etter å blitt lagret ett år. Vi har smakt en my og en som har blitt lagret ett rom

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500 ml bottle @ Tilt Bar, Oslo.December 06,2012
Tasted from a tulip glass
Color is dark brown.Aroma is malt, caramel, red fruits,chestnuts  and spices.
Taste is a bit sweet and malty. Medium carbonation.Wonderful warming and a christmas beer full of aroma.
Aroma is juniper berries and some mild spicy heat.  The flavor is malts, nuttiness from the chestnuts, medium sweetness and a mix of tart and mildly sour in the finish.

Bottle 2012. Pours deep amber with an off-white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, sweet red fruits with some spice and herbal notes. Flavor is sweet and malty with some red fruits, burnt sugar and spices. Medium body, average carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2012 50 cl bottle. Batch #526. Brewed on 03.08.2010. BBE 03.08.2015. Vertical with Nøgne Ø / Jolly Pumpkin / Stone version.
Licorice, spices, ripe fruits on the nose, same thing on the flavor. Improved a lot in two years.
50 cl bottle.
Originally rated on 20101107. (7-4-7-3-14)
Pours hazy brown color with a small head. Aroma of spices, malts, some hops, fruits and herbal notes. Flavor of spices, malts, caramel notes, fruits and some nuts. Decent.

Bottle shared by Thorpe429 at the Christmas in July party. Thanks Mike!

The beer is brown, with a small head that fades rapidly, leaving minimal lacing. The aroma is grandiose, with pine, Christmas spices, and alcohol. The flavor brings a huge pine needle flavor, like drinking Christmas tree juice with cinnamon and nutmeg sprinkled on top. The body is thin, and the flavor, while decent, is overbearing. I would prefer more balance and subtlety. A small portion was more than enough for me.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-20-2011
UPDATED: DEC 10, 2012 Great holiday ale with nice taste and aroma. Christmas is all around, and some other and more exotic aromas too.

A-- Gusher right from opening the cap. Once settled down it poured a dark mahogany brown and settled even darker. Light brown head settled to just above film but has good head retention. Big two finger head in the bottle!! No lacing.

S-- All over the place. Vanilla, Cinnamon, Juniper berry. Smells more like a big spicy vanilla candle that you light at Christmas. Really good nose.

T-- A lot of vanilla, juniper, and sage. Cinnamon and the malt are in the background. A lot of flavor in this and the juniper berries and sage really stand out. Spice with a lot of flavor.

M-- Pretty high carbonation but works well for what is in it and what it is. The amount of spices have a numbing effect on my tongue and in effect have killed the taste buds. After it warms up more it tastes more the chestnuts come out more and leave a big nutty flavor and the beer becomes more alcoholic. 


O-- good winter warmer on steroids

Pours burnt caramel amber with a sandy head. The aroma brings sweet, sugary dark fruits present and prevalent in the nose, less tart than it used to be. The flavor is smooth and tart, notes of apple and the acetyl have set in a bit, but used to be juicier and more tart when it was fresh. The body is just medium to thick perfect.

2009 bottle, batch 2 with Pat a few years ago before Christmas. Surprised I havent rated this awesome holiday brew. Pours a brown cola color with thick white head, good lacing. Aromas are filled with chestnut smoke, juniper berry, cinnamon, cardamom, and chocolate. Taste is pine, berries, cocoa powder, spruce tips, dark fruits, and all spice. Smooth and creamy brew that kept us wanting more.

From notes: Poured hazy, deep nut brown with a small, thin tan head that was gone quickly.  Deep, sweet candied fruit aroma that was vaguely reminiscent of herbal cough drops.  Full-bodied, with a very slight thickness to it.  Flavor was chocolatey, with evergreen notes beneath.  Added a nutty note as it warmed.
Very spicy and delightful.  A deep brown color with a hint of amber. A slow sipper that leaves you satisfied.
0.5 l bottle. Sweet herbal and perfumy aroma with camphor, anise, great . Sweet spicy flavor with anise, juniper, licorice, bitter tonic (fernet). Spicy in a very nice way, stunning perfumed aroma.

Bottle thanks to a close friend ! 
head: small, away fast 
Colour: dark brown 
Smell: Strong herbal, loads of anise and bitter spices, coughsirup, bit of booze, bit of brown sugar 
Taste: start is like jaegermeister but less sweet and more bitter, also reminds a bit of Underberg after dinner bitter, bit of anise, touch of candy sirup, just a slight bit of booze and a touch of orange peels in the end , end is dry aftertaste is bitter/herbal , not bad actually ...

Bottle to oversized snifter.  Looks decent; dark with very little lacing or CO2.  Smells pretty good; spicy.  Tastes decent; a little too much going on for my preference though.  Mouthfeel is okay.  Overall, a bit of a disappointment, considering the collaborators.

Bottle shared by akevitt.  Pours a cloudy dark brown body with light brown head.  Strong juniper aroma with holiday spices, mainly nutmeg and cinnamon along with some sage caramel malts, and nuts.  Flavor is similar, rather malty and sweet with a light rye spiciness.  Thicker mouthfeel than expected, although soft on the palate.  Slight juniper/pine flavor on the finish.  Definitely interesting.

Tasted as part of a line up of all three versions
Appearance - Pours a ruby/mahogany color with a thin tan head which settles quickly. Nice clarity. Good lacing. A fluffy head forms in the bottle as it waits for the next person to have a pour.

Aroma - Right of the bat I can detect a difference with this beer from the Stone version.  Where Stones level of spice was what I would describe as hard this one is more smooth.  I wonder if it is an age issue. I like the more tame aroma.

Mouthfeel - Medium level of carbonation. Definitely more carbonated then the Stone version which really works for the beer.

Taste - No hops to balance out the high level of spices. Very malty. No Rye. The juniper is more tame then the Stone version.  Does a great job in covering up the 9% abv in the beer.

Overall - Much more enjoyable then the Stone version.  Out of the three versions this one ranks first for taste and second for aroma.
aroma of spice and raisin or grape. 2010 bottle. Thicker than I imagined it would be. Lots of nutmeg and allspice in a smooth beer. Some chocolate as it warms.

0.5l bottle from Pinch poured into a snifter. Pours black with a half finger of dark tan head. Aroma of pine, sugar, caramel, grape jelly and spices. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Sugar, pine, coffee and spices. Full bodied with thick and sticky texture. Soft carbonation and a long finish. Overall, its pretty good. Very complex. There is something weird in the aftertaste that Im not a big fan of but overall, its very good.

A - pours dark orange brow with high head, no lacing. 

S - cider and spices, earthy notes. Subtle alcohol. 

M - medium/ heavy body with no carb. Lingering sweet malty ending. 

T - cider and spices on the nose. Pears and sweet dark fruits on the palate. Lingering sweet dark malty ending. Strange taste of cough syrup on the tip of the tongue. Hints of over ripe purple grapes. 

O - pretty good dark spicy beer. Very fruity(dark fruits, grapes, cider).  

7-

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

in bottle at urge thanks to the very nice lady next to me that night at the bar.  Smells of lots of spices and cinnamon.  Looks very dark brown.  Tastes delicious with nuttiness and spices on a thickish palate.  the perfect holiday style ale that i could imagine. I so want the recipe for this so i can make some of my own.  Overall 8.5 of 10.

Pours dark brown-black with a thin fluffy off-white head. Aroma is spicy, clove, earthy, herbal, some citrus and black licorice. Taste is earthy, herbal, spicy, black licorice and cough syrup. Mild carbonation. Nice overall.

Black, brown head. Smells very sweet - I get some grape jam, the an little spruce or juniper. Viscous, heavy palate. spicy, piney and juniper. If I concentrate really hard, I get sage. Dry, woody finish. Everything seems a little muddled, to be honest. Thanks to grownfool for this one!

Pours a deep tan .. light foam .. . katrell is an old skank .. . spice and dark fruit mostly .. fairly simple brew, has a clean finish .. . decent but i liked the stone version a tad better i think .. . You know what would make a good story? Something about a clown who make people happy, but inside hes real sad. Also, he has severe diarrhea..

A collaboration ale from three awesome brewers leads to high expectations.  Ill call it a fancy nut brown ale.  Chestnuts provide the strongest note.  The juniper berries are next and sage is the faint note which supports the chord nicely.  I pick up some raisin which probably isnt there.  There are also faint notes of cardamom and cola.  Id be happy to drink several more of these, if they didnt cost $10 a pint.

Poured from a 650ml bottle into a pint glass.

A: Resembles a soft drink actually, opaque deep chestnut in the middle with a deep red/brown on the edges. Carbonation is stuck to the sides of the glass and theres a thin, but resilient creamy tan head. Very appealing looking beer, as if itll quench my thirst.

S: Odd smell, it actually reminds me of a Coke or a Pepsi on the nose with the allspice and cinnamon. Some herbs come through, maybe sage? As the beer warms up theres a smell of a brown nut.

T: Very interesting flavor here, some rye hints with a brown nut profile. Some earthy flavors from herbs of some sort. At the very end I get a tinge of a roasted flavor.

M: Creamy yet syrupy, this is quite thick and theres not much carbonation if any at all.

O: This is an interesting beer, it has a brown nut ale semblance to it, but its rather complex. I wouldnt buy this again, but its definitely good for the season.
Nose Is ginger bread, weak port, cedar wood, vanilla, cardamom, feel Is mediumbroad, carb Is medium, taste is oak, wine, sweet hazel, later decent, but very sweet alcohol

bottle, from TJs beverage. no date or batch indicated where is suppose to be. Good aroma, sweet, spice. caramel, chocolate, sage and juniper are strong. Dark orangy brown color. Good head that fade quick to a ring, no lace. Sweet flavor. Full body, creamy oily mouthfeel,sweet dry finish. Me like this one. Like an alcoholic rootbeer. Aroma is my favorite part. real nice spice and sweet mix. well done winter spice beer
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text:
Bottle enjoyed at Haandverkerstuene
Pours dark brown with a thin excuisite espresso head that leaves nice lacings. Smells of caramel, juniper, sage,  nutmeg and christmas spices, also small hints of some coffee. Taste is super malty, good sweetness with nice spice tones. Also some hints of alcohol. Oily palate. Nice bitter finish.Glad i finally got to try this edition. Its so totally different than the JP edition. Really cool cooperation
Ive had this one cellared since late 2010. The aroma is awesome ... Very spicy. Color is blak with a frothy head. The taste has nutmeg and some other comforting spices. Great winter holiday beer.

After weekend where I was forced to entertain both my inlaws and parents cracked this puppy for some much need relaxation.  Pours very dark brown with small tan head.  Nose is wonderful of berries and pine.  Tastes of juniper berries, apples, toffee, pine, spices, and light booze.  Perfect carbonation this is hitting spot.

500mL bottle.  Relatively thick pour; almost completely opaque with off-white head.  Aroma is juniper, pine, anise, apple, alcohol.  Flavor is sweeter than aroma: juniper, pine, anise, chocolate, misc spices.  Creamy mouthfeel with a juniper/anise lingering finish.  Amazing beer!

This beer has a ton of spruce and licorice - two things that I absolutely love.  Pours a dark coffee brown with a wispy thin dark ale head.  
Aroma is licorice and spruce, taste is the same.  Some dark unsweetened chocolate on the palate, but  that is overpowered by the spruce.  This beer is outstanding!!

500mL bottle, pours a hazy orange brown. Aroma of various Christmas spices - nutmeg, cinnamon, coriander, etc. Flavour mixes these together quite well, without any harsh edges. Not my favourite style, but well-done for what it is.

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2012 Bottle at the brewery. Hazy deep dark colour with a off white head. Aroma is comlex with a lot of christmas spices. Well blended and have a very balanced touch. Absolutely an unique full-bodied ale.
Bottle. Dark brown. Spiced. Fruits, malts. If the flavor had been more focused it couldve been a great one.
From Total Wine. On discount.  Pours dark but next to no head.  Taste is of Windex and Mexican bathroom cleaner.  Fail.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a decent light tan head. Light hops in the aroma with a hint of caramel and roasted malt. Light, and I mean very light coffee taste with some hops in the background. Really solid, and has that Stone footprint as well with the hops. Well done.

Sampled (again towards the end of a long night) at one of marks tastings I believe.  Nutmeg and holiday spice flavor.  and jagermister!  This was good, but Id love to be able to try these three varieties side by side to try and pick out the differences.

Bottle picked up a ways back, I believe at Capones. Served in a SAVOR snifter at our Christmas in July party last weekend.

Pours a moderate brown-copper color with a slight off-white head and a bit of lacing. The nose brings loads of pine needs and a bit of nutmeg and cinnamon. The flavor takes it down a notch and everything is quite palatable; the pine and spices blend quite well. Smooth feel and a medium body. Pretty good.

Serving type: bottle

Some nice flavours, but maybe theres even too much of them.
(This beer rating was imported from FB and unfortunately lacks any further comments.)

Det här är altså Nøgnes variant (har provat Stones tidigare)
Mycket krydrig och lite bärig (jag tycker faktisk det doftar blåbär)
Lite tunn smak och aningen tvärr bismak.

Bottle.

Hazy dark brown with a small head. Very special aroma and taste, almost like "Christmas". Roasted malt, dried fruit, ginger, juniper. Too spicy taste for my liking, a pretty tough beer after a while. Interesting experiment, but as I said, too spicy.
Aroma of cinnamon, pine, sage, perfume. Taste is overpowering. Its like drinking a perfume bottle. Blech.

500 ml bottle into tulip, almost a gusher upon opening.  Pours dark brown color with a nice 2 finger dense light tan head with good retention.  Some decent lacing on the glass as well.  Aromas of ginger, cinnamon, all spice, roasted malt, molasses, and nuttiness. Taste of tons of cinnamon, clove, all spice, ginger, and nuttiness in the front; that leads to strong notes of toffee, caramel, and molasses on the back.  Big lingering notes of roasted malt, caramel, and molasses with spices after the finish.  Great balance of flavors as well.  Nice smooth medium-full body with fairly high carbonation.  Drinkability is great for the level of alcohol.  No alcohol noticed in the taste and a slight warming after the finish.  Overall an excellent winter warmer, probably the best one I have had yet.
500ml bottle shared by jsprime. dark brown with a tan head. dark malt and herbal nose. the flavour is totally dominated by the herbs. almost undrinkable at this point.

Bottle. Pours an unclear and brown beer with a beige head. The aroma is malt, caramel, ginger and spices. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness. Overall an average beer with a high level of spices.
Bottle @ Odense tasting. Brown body with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is light tiger balm, spices, cinnamon and notes of coca cola?. Flavor is caramel, spices, notes of berries. Well carbonated.
Pours copper with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, vanilla, cinnamon and clove. Flavour is caramel, cinnamon, clove and co2.

Brown with a small off-white head. Complex spice aroma with cardemum and clove dominating. Caramel notes and a hint of peppermint. Sweet spiced flavour with a hint of roasted character. For a completely over-spiced beer (something I dont like) its reasonably drinkable.

Seems wrongly categorized. Hops blend well with spices to male nice flavor of Sharp pine, nuts, and all spice. Deep malt holds it all well. Nice beer, bet it was better two months or more age with sharper hop.

Gewürziger Antrunk von Beeren und Kürbis, die nicht so ganz zueinander passen wollen. Das Malz wirkt ausgleichend und kann zum Ende den Geschmack an sich reißen, die Gewürze agiere hier geschickter und drängen sich nicht mehr auf. Nettes, zu Beginn aber überwürztes Bier. 5/8/9/11/10/9

Bottle @ Odense Tasting, May 2011. Trade with Yngwie. Thanks. Pours dark brown with a small creamy head on top. Cinnamon, sage, berries and caramel. Various spices. Smooth and full bodied. Finally a spiced beer that really works. Well composed.
Bottle. Dark brown pour with a small off white head. Nose is predominantly ginger and spice. Complex spices on the nose, coriander, ginger, nuts. Almost fruitcakeish

500 mL bottle.  Dark brown to black pour with a light tan head.  Aroma has tons of juniper berry, sage, and cool medicinal cherry.  Flavor is very strongly spiced with the juniper berry, cinnamon, and again medicinal sensation.  Hints of roasted malts beneath.  Quite heavy on the spices, but it still works out decently.
Bottle at home ... deep brown black ... thin tan lacing ... sweet toffee light spiced malt nose ... soft light sweet body ... juicy woody toffee malts ... dark fruits ...

22 April 2011, bottle w/ cgarvieuk. dark red. a bit like a tart grape and wine with some vinagrette and some holiday spices. med body and slightly fizzy. grape jam and christmas spices. really interesting and kind of fun.

Bottle @ home. Dull orange brown appearance with a tan head. Sweet citrusy, grapefruity, spicy, juniper, spruce, cinnamon, cardamom, holiday ale nose. Quite spicy (orange peel?), cinnamon, cardamom, juniper, spruce ale flavor. Spicy, sprucey, slightly citrusy finish. A really good, spiced holiday ale in the same line as the Anchor Christmas.

Pours a hazy chestnut brown with a one finger sized head. The aroma is extremely spicy, the caraway really shows, and the juniper plays second fiddle. The flavor is nutty and spicy. Juniper really shows through. Really nice, weird but nice.

Bottle. Pours inky tarry brown, very odd colored beer. 1-finger tan head, poor lacing. Nose is massive cardamom and caraway, smells rather strikingly like my cupboard where I keep my Indian spices. Gorgeous and pungent nose. Flavours of big cardamom, sage, hot peppers, cola, candies, like the little cola bottles. Spicy as hell and incredibly enjoyable.
Very interesting spice flavors, the species add instead of overtaking the flavor in this beer, delicious brew.

Bottle. Cola colored pour with similar cola style head. Aroma is surprising Ginger and root beer some vanilla and a earthy spices. Taste is creamy malt and Ginger ale with lots of sweet spices. Palate is medium mouthfeel with a good carbonation and finishes chaulky. Very interesting brew, but enjoyed quite abit. Glad  I found it on closeout, I had been eyeing it up for awhile now.

Bottle. Moderate malt notes of toasted cereal, caramel and cookie, perfume and herbs for the hops, light earth for the yeast, with hints of brown sugar and root beer. Head is small, fizzy turning wispy, light tan, with some slippery lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is very dark brown with thin sediments on the bottom. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes moderately sweet, lightly acidic and faintly bitter. Palate is medium, slick with a lively carbonation and a sticky finish. Lots of herb and spice in this Holiday Ale. This beer was a nice reminder of past Christmas during the winter thaw.
Draft @ Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Pours a black color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy aroma. Fruity malty spicy herbal chcolate flavor. Has a roasted malty fruity spicy finish.

Bottle. Orange-kissed deep amber brown. Aroma is very intriguing: spicy mace, light gingerbread, cocoa. Flavours are even more so, with nutmeg, soft conifer, herbal earthy mint (Im guessing that is the sage) all combined with sweet honey cake and pumpernickel malts. Really intriguing and tasty.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Poured as a deep dark brown color with a creamy tan layer of foam. The aroma is rich and robust with a mixture of different elements that confuses my nose, and only because it was mentioned on the bottle, did I agree with the sage and juniper berries, but there is also minor syrup like scent and a worthy salivating smokiness in the faint background. Flavors are bold and strong with spices and herbs that make this a delicious Christmas ale. Some of the ingredients I noticed were nutmeg, mint, sage, and an upfront serving of pine.
Bottle 500ml from old notes. Cant read the texts on the note, need to re-rate.

Near black colored with red hints, medium sized beige head. Strong licorice aroma dominating with juniperry touch, some roastiness and sweetness here as well. Medium to full bodied, soft palate. Flavor is sweet as well with same dominating licorice, some soapy juniper and grassy hops come up too. Aftertaste dries with still full palated mouthfeel, licorice here too.

Bottle at the 5th Annual Richmond Industry Gathering on 11/28/2010. Cloudy orange body with a small tan head. Big spice and caramel aroma. Huge pumpkin and spice flavor. Medium body with moderately high carbonation.

Bottle and served in NB Worthy glass next to my remaining bottle of  Stone/Nøgne Ø/JP Special Holiday Ale (which already rated at 4.0 previously, but will rerate at 3.7) and the JP/Nøgne Ø/Stone Collababeire Special Holiday Ale: Deep chestnut brown with a fading but lasting off-white creamy head and good lace. The aroma has notes of chestnut, roast, sage, juniper, gin, clean oak, honeycomb, and some very earthy and almost leathery ester. The taste starts quite spicy and pretty much stays the course. The sage and juniper intermix produces an almost piney character similar to Stone bottled version. But unlike the Stone version, this is much more malty and less bitter and astrengent... which is not a good thing. Sure is very holiday like, but is too much of a good thing IMO, If Tom thought that the Stone version was too much he would really hate this one. The mouth feel of this brew is actually the best of the lot, nearly full-bodied, dry but oily too. The alcohol seems least noticeable in the beer as well.  Of the three versions, this is my least favorite because it is the least balanced nor complex. (note that the oldest Stone released version is going a tad downhill and I would likely give it only a 3.7 rating now)

Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head. Spicy aroma with some caramel malty notes and some choco. Strong caramel up front with some toastiness. Mid range body. Finish is spicy but clean. Interesting beer.

Bottle at Stone Winterstorm 2011.  Dark cola brown.  Thick latte lace and tiny ring.  Light roast malt nose and high sweet.  Taste is way bigger than nose.  Suprisingly so.  Clove and vanilla.  Spices and a huge thick mouthfeel.  Great beer.

Opened up the Nogne version of the  bottle that I had cellared for a year, poured into a Belgian goblet type glass. Dark brown, opaque with at milky tan head initially that recedes quickly. Flowery floral aroma -- lavender soapy scents. I taste more lavender and a ginger spicy notes. This blends well with a cocoa powder in the background that gives me an all around mouthfeel that reminds of a spiced cocoa on a cold winters day. The cocoa taste last long into the finish, giving the beer a pleasant lingering sensation. I get more of a light to medium bodied creamy and milky mouthfeel. Nice holiday beer that I really enjoyed and would definitely seek out again if it were available -- too bad this was only a one time collaboration effort.

Amazing beer  Dark mahogany pour with a small beige head. Aroma holds tons of herbal notes, with sage and rosemary dominant. Also notes of carraway, rye, and some nuttiness- very intriguing on the nose. Flavor is similar to the aroma, with lots of sage and increased nuttiness. Awesome stuff, particularly for the style

Bottle @ home. Pours dark with moderate head. A strong and good malt base with a balanced hop profile. The spices are in here but not as prominent as one would believe. Is it better than the version brewed at Stone? Its different.

Flaske 0,5l batch 528 fra Vinmonopolet i Tromsø. Så vidt gjennomskinnelig: Dypt rødbrun. Egentlig svart. Høyt beige skum som varer lenge og legger igjen mønster på glassveggen. Sterk aroma med krydder og harpiks i forgrunnen. Julestemning! Fløyelsmyk munnfølelse. Godt integrerte smaker med krydder, nøtter & frukt. Ikke påtrengende. Overgang til en fruktig, tørr bitter ettersmak med skogspreg. Et utmerket øl.
Pours black with a tiny beige head. Smells slightly spicy. Sweet with aromas of spices and some too fresh chestnut aromas. Medium bodied. Dry finish. Not good.
Olmost black with light brown head - aroma is right away a lot of spices - taste is of solid sweet malt body, and again a lot of spices, all in a good combination - very good and easy drinking beer

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2011 In short: A straightforward toasted, sweet and nutty dark ale.  A bit boring.
How: Bottle 500ml.  Consumed when approximately one year of age.  Bottle sent to me by  brewolf? (not sure about this one)
The look: Very dark brown body topped by a very small dark beige head
In long: Nose of roasted nuts, wood coal.  Taste of burnt brown sugar, nutty caramel fudge, tree bark, spicy notes, some bananas, some floral notes.  Supposed to used berries but I didnt find much berries at and not much fruity flavors for that matter.  It might because of the age difference (I had the Stone version fresher) but I found this Nogne version simpler with all th focus on plain sweet nutty malts.  I thought the first version (Stone) was a bit odd and find this second version a bit bland.  Basically they are both just ok beer for different reasons.  Im not sure if these will be made again but they were not interesting enough so Im not planning to re-rate them.  Anyway in fifty years from now none of my ratings are really going to matter,  mostly because of the fact that none of them really matter now.

bottle. pours auburn-brown, with creamy off white head. heavily spiced aroma with cloves, cardamom, anise, licorice, and brown sugar. flavors of brown sugar, cloves, cardamom, caramelized malt balls. nice coating palate that finished dry and clean. aroma is too spiced up for me but the flavor and drinkability is rewarding. tasty brew!

500ml bottle contributed by Andrew... Pours a darker toffee caramel with a thinnish light beige head... Menthol and thyme mostly upfront with some backing caramel and chocolate malt... Flavors allow the malt to come through a bit more without the spice and in my eyes, definitely in my eyes.  Deeper caramels and toast... Body is medium to full with a nice creaminess. Flavors were much better than the spice forward aroma.
Another really fine one from Nøgne. Not as spicy as many christmas beer, still unique and interesting.

Pours dark amber with medium off white head that retains well and laces quite nicely. Smells like an amazing blend of sage, sweet spicy crystalline ginger, fresh juniper, cardamom, nutmeg, pine and roasted malt. Tastes like roasted malt, anise, juniper, ginger, and fresh sage with the slightest hint of bitter cold coffee and grassy fresh hop. Medium body with a silky palate, nice carbonation and a really lovely long, dry, spiced finish.

Dark red pour, little head.  Spices galore on the nose...ginger and sage dominate.  The flavor is slightly fruity, slight tart, slightly sweet...bundled well.  Junipar, sage, and spice are present as thick malts sweep across the palate.  Fairly carbonated.  Long spicey hopped finish presents itself and lingers nicely with each sip.
Really incredible, a standout beer amongst many excellent holiday ales available.

Tasted on 1/2/11 from a 500mL bottle at Lush Roscoe.  Pours dark but clear amber with an average beige head that leaves a thin  but even layer of lace.  The nose is cardamom, nicely toasted malt, and other baking spices.  The flavor is sweet brown sugar and toasted malt up front moving to dusty cardamom and darkly roasted coffee, and finishing with a eucalyptus note.  The body  is medium with lively carbonation and a long eucalyptus and roasted finish.

Pours a dark reddish brown, almost plum tinted. Less than a finger of off-white head. Smells just like Christmas: dried fruit, spruce hops, and spices most notably ginger and juniper. Taste is fruity and sweet, much like an Abbey Dubbel. Quite a bit of roasted malts and berry sweetness (a cherry flavor comes through, even though I dont believe cherries were used in the brewing), alongside flavors from the aroma. Not sure that this one is worth the high price tag; but, if youre really invested in any of the three collaborative breweries or spice beers, it may be worth the price tag.

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of yngwie. Hazy nutty brown with a beige head. Sweetish spicy nose. Quite full-bodied, some burned caramel, roasted malt and nuts with a fairly interesting spice profile. Subdued bitterness. Interesting. 251210

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2010 Very dark red on the pour.  Very little light breaking through this hazy concoction.  A full dense head forms and remains for a good time, leaving nice attractive lacing behind.  Loads of ginger, sage, and juniper berries in the aroma.  Also some hints of chocolate and pine are noticeable.  The aroma is very much like the first batch being full of spices and complex malts.  Very spicey on the palate and a strong dry hoppiness on the palate.  Some chocolate malt coming through as well as a hint of mocha.  The finish is rather bitter and dry from the hops.  This really isnt my favorite.  While the flavors do not really suit my palate, I can not deny that this beer is brewed carefully and done well.  Its a good beer, just not my tastes.

pours a very dark cloudy brownish red color. minimal head. interesting aroma. cant quite put my finger on it but definately some fruit in the nose.almost a mint smell as well which i assume could possibly be the sage. extremely pleasant brew. tastes like a typical brown ale but with something extra. the spices really round this ale out and make it something else. easy to drink and relatively complex in flavor.  could possibly be sessionable if it wasnt so expensive. i would love to see this in a 4 or 6 pack.

Certainly a nice beer and unique.  Nose is very strong with what comes across as ginger, but is probably a mix of the sage and various other additives.  Mouthfeel is not what you would expect and is incredibly smooth, making this beer a bit more drinkable than the nose would lead you to believe.

500 ml bottle. Batch #526. Finland.
Dark brown colour with small creamy tan head.
Salt, aniseed, ginger, liquorice, spices and roasted malt in intriguing aroma.
Flavour is roasted malt, bitterish hops to balance and salt, aniseed, ginger, liquorice and some other spices. Smooth as silk. This is a real treat.

Appearance:  Pours a dark brown with a frothy creamy tan head. Leaves behind spotty lacing.

Aroma: Sage, Aquafresh toothpaste, chocolate roast. The sage and mint toothpaste are the most dominate odors.

Taste:  Chocolate chip mint, roasted chestnuts, roasty malt. Finishes herbal and nutty.  The roast lends a little bit of bitterness, but by no means a bitter beer.

Mouthfeel:  Medium bodied, creamy carbonation.

Overall:  I cant recall the first batch very well, but this comes off as a brand new beer to my elephant like memory.

Bottle. Dark amber-brown, thick offwhite head. Nose is pumpkin and sage with hints of gin-like juniper. Flavor is spices and fruit/berries up front with a solid bread and sweet crust malt underlying, hints of cocoa, light hop bitterness and flavor to balance, finishes sweet. Medium-full body, thick texture, modest carbonation. A very delicious holiday ale with nice layers of complexity, clean and smooth sweetness, balanced without cloyingness.

(bottle - 500 ml) Deep copper pour with a fizzy off-white head. Aroma is full of spices and other various ingredients. Definitely got hints of mint and the juniper berries. Not so much with the chestnuts, but then again I dont know what they smell like. Flavor is minty (from the sage perhaps?) and spicy with a myriad of different holiday flavors. Nice and sweet with a very herbal finish and aftertaste. Rather nice.

Bottle; Pour is a dark brown with light beige head. Rims the glass, with decent retention. The sage does dominate here. That in itself is different ; without reading the bottle, I thought at first when sampling this brew that I was pulling nutmeg out of it , but I think it is more a combination of the sage and the juniper berries. There is a general spiciness in this brew on the tongue and the bitterness is present here as well. You do get a bit of sweetness from the malts - and it seems a bit boozy, for whatever reason. Im trying my hardest to sense the chestnuts in this brew and it was only at the very end of the flavor profile that it finally came out - it took quite a while really, and so I would call that element subdued and wouldnt have known it if I were tasting this blindly.
great holiday ale.   Oats adds thickness.  spices meld wonderfully in aroma and taste.

12/11/10 notes: on tap. Pour is dark chocolate color, opaque, and with a tan head.  Nose is mild of dark malts, swirling hops, earthier grains.  Flavor follows suit with a splash of hops up front, some bittersweet notes in middle with hints of molasses and nuttiness.  To be honest, not seeing much herbal-spice influence here. Mild hop finish. Good balance, but tasted blind (as in, unfamiliar with spices added) this beer felt a little underwhelming.
Dark brown with a big fluffy tan head.  Strong aroma of cola nut and spice and tastes of chocolate, orange, juniper and light sage with a candy finish.

500mL bottle, about a year old.  Poured medium, rubied brown with a creamy, well-retained khaki head.  The aroma picked up very aggressive juniper and sage upfront over mostly nutty sweetness.. some smoke and vanilla evident upon closer inspection.. intriguing!  The flavor found tart berries and almost metallic character upfront.. juniper berries gave some sweetness along with nutty notes at the core.. sage gripped the middle of the palate, and joined juniper tartness to dominate the back-end.. dry, earthy and toasty oxidation on the back.. left a mint-like refreshingness after the drink.  Medium-bodied and well-carbonated on the palate.. syrupy across the middle.. only flowed decently.. overall a very solid brew.

Pours dark ruddy brown with a 4 finger, creamy, light beige head that has good retention and leaves incredible sheets of lacing. Aroma is huge on pie spice and sage, and other herbs and spices that would taste good with poultry, a touch of bread and light roast, this stuff smells like it belongs on poultry. Flavor is full of Christmas spices, like really full, nutmeg, cinnamon, allspice, bell peppers, clove  and some sage, thats about it, pretty much all spice in the flavor, a little roast and dark caramel. Palate is pretty heavy bodied, super creamy on entry right up to the fade where it dries out quite a bit and has a light, velvety carbonation,. Very strange beer, taste like poultry and pie seasonings together quite strongly.

500 ml bottle purchased a year ago at Holiday Wine Cellar ($9.89).  Pours a very dark -- almost opaque -- garnet with a finger and a half of beige foam.  Aroma is very herbal and spicy with notes of sage, anise/caraway, juniper, spruce, and ginger.  The nose has hints of heavier malt notes, but it is the herbal-ness that is front and center here.  Flavor is also quite herbal (even kind of medicinal) with more sage, juniper, and spruce.  After the initial herbal tastes, a more malty presence is noticeable with notes of chocolate, rye bread, caramel, and maple.  Nice creamy mouthfeel with lightly bitter-medicinal finish.  It definitely smells and tastes like a good holiday ale, but Im not sure if I could drink this more than once a year.  I remember when this was first brewed locally and it was one of Stones very first collaboration ales.  And I also remember it was a lot cheaper when it was made locally here in San Diego.  (253, 430)

On tap at HopCat, Grand Rapids. Murky orange-brown body, almost no head. Spicy nose with cardamom and pepper. Slick, rich body, with caramel, toffee, berries, cardamom, and other spices. An oily, slick, thick beer, with warming but not sharp alcohol tones adding some life to the heavy palate. Probably best enjoyed a few ounces at a time.
Interesting taste. I  had this with duck and although that wasnt the best combination I still like the taste. But Im not sure if Ill buy this again.

500 mL bottle at the 5th Annual Epic Beer Tasting in Richmond, VA, November 28, 2010. Pours a hazy reddish brown color with a medium tan head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of big spicy notes, citrus, toffee and pine. The taste is pine, spruce, cinnamon and other spices. Medium bodied.
Draught at Patricks Pub Kristiansand. Pours dark ruby with a small white head. Aroma is roasted malts, alcohol, clove, herbs and licorice. Taste light sweetness, lightly bitter.

Thanks to oddefellow for the share.  Pours brown with an off-white head.  Nose is roasted nuts, lots of sage, spice, pepper, and complexity.  Flavor follows along those lines, with the sage being the dominant spice.  Interesting, and strikingly more complex than I remember last years.
Pours thick, like a warm maple syrup.  Color is a dark amber with a light colored head.  Aroma of sage and dark malt.  Taste is full from front to back of mouth.  Slight bite of alcohol present.
Draught at Patricks Pub Kristiansand. Pours red/black with white head. A taste that stays with you. Taste of pumpkin is a treat.

(16.9oz bottle).  Pours almost black with khaki head.  Aroma of sage, juniper and spices. Taste is sweet with some roastiness and hop bitterness.  The sage is quite strong and I find it distracting. There are  some chocolate notes that help with balancing the sage, but ultimately, it doesnt work.

Courtesy of Oddefellowe. Pours murky copper with tan head. The aroma is full up menthal Ben-Gay-ness, peppermint, herbaliness, mintiness and a sweet nuttiness. The taste is yummy spicy herbal, brown sugar mixing with various menthal winter mint like notes and sweet nuttiness. Very interesting indeed.

From bottle into a belles glass. Appearance is a dark, dense black with a thin tan head. Aroma is nuts, spices, malt, and alcohol. Taste is sweet and toffee-like with notes of nuts, dark fruits, and alcohol. Heavy bodied and the alcohol comes throughout plainly in the palate but not unpleasantly. It makes me want to drink this beer by a fireside while eating some mincemeat pie.

Bottle pours deep brown with a creamy tan head.  Aroma is spicy with notes of ginger, cinnamon, juniper, and caramel.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of nuts, anise, raisins, a touch of coffee, and other spices that I cant quite put my finger on. Overall body is moderate and soft with nice balanced bitterness.

500 ml bottle. Black, but brown at the edges. Clear. Small beige fine-laced head. Spicy aroma with notes of eucalyptus, ginger and cinnamon, and probably a lot more as well. The flavours are very complex, and surprisingly bready and toffee-like. Crisp and distinctive flavours as always from Nøgne Ø. Leans towards the bitter side, but there is enough malt and spice complexity to balance this well. Im glad theres a lot more of this beer in the cellar. Yummy.
Bottle 50 cl. Pours black colour with a beige head. Aroma is liquorice, anise and coffee. Flavour of liquorice, juniper, berries and hints of coffee. Creamy mouthfeel with a bit of sweet finish.

50cl bottle from Alko. Batch # 526, BB: 3/8/2015. Poured dark brown with a nice head, some lacing. Aroma is intensely spicy: ginger, clove and cinnamon. Flavor is similar, clove, ginger and dr.pepper. Oily mouthfeel, long finish with some piney notes. Excellent, truly unique beer.
0.5l bottle Tampa Wkly Gathering @TampaPourhouse Thanks James-pours a light tan head with brown color.  Aroma is sage/campho, medium malt.  Taste follows.  Easy.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2010 Dark brown beer with little floaties. Light brown head. Spicy, vegetable aroma. Extremely spicy flavour. Perhaps a litte like Jägermeister or cough syrup. Of all of the spices, the presence of cardemomme is most obvious. After a while its getting a little tough for me to consume this.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar. Low fluffy quickly disappearing white head. Pitch black body. Cinamon raisin aroma. Vineous cinamon raisin flavor with caramel and coriandder. Low carbonation, long aftertaste.

500 ml bottle. Deep dark brown colour, thin light beige head. Sweet and spicy aroma of roasted malts and dark fruits. The flavour is very much like the aroma: caramel-sweet, roasted, with dark fruits, liquorice and spices. Delicious and creamy.

dark brown body, brown 
head. Surprisingly nice aroma of spices. Juniper, caraway and caramel. Very good flavor too. Good bitterness and acidicity. I was blown away.

Bottle:pours a deep cola brown.chocolate white head, thins to a permanent ring around the glass.barnyard,dough, roasted coffee bean.spice on the nose.lighter mouthfeel lighter than expected. fairly smooth. The finish is really spicy and long. definitely unique. would have again.

50cl bottle. Dark reddish brown colour with a medium-sized tan head. Very spicy aroma with some roasted malt and juniper berries. Very spicy flavour with notes of malt, sweetness and some herbs. Quite full body, oily mouthfeel. Quite good but maybe a bit too much spiciness.

Pours dark brown with a light head. Aroma is roasted malts and spices, flavor is much of the same but stronger. A little sweet and very bitter, perhaps almost too bitter for me. Tastes much stronger than it is which is saying much, since its quite strong.

Barril. Black colour. Quite spiced liqourice sweet dark fruity roast aroma. Good mouthfeel. Sweet dark fruity spiced roasty malty flavour with chcocolate, liqourice and ginger. Tasty Christmas brew indeed.

Bottle. Dark brown, small and fully diminishing light brown head. Moderate and very spicy aroma sweetish (licorice and aniseed). Body is medium, malty and sweetish flavor, licorice and aniseed. Finish is moderate and spicy. WellToo much spice.

{thoughts} A robust strong ale with supple spice additions, juicy malts, balancing bitterness and a most luxurious mouthfeel.

{elements} Clear, cola-brown hue; thick, light brown cream. Juniper and chestnuts fuse into a cola-like aroma with a muted spicy-earthy background over a broad malty base; hints of clove and polished leather with a late-developing cocoa note. Bold, malty sweetness, soft acidity, moderate background bitterness. Absolutely expert mouthfeel --superbly creamy texture, plush carbonation, full bodied. 50 cl bottle, best during 03/08/10-15.

Draught @ Henriks Bergen. Pours deep dark brown with a large longlasting beige head. Nose is quite spicy and nutty with caramel notes. Taste is rich on liquorish and spices with a nice sweet-malty and fruity finish. A really good Christmas brew - Perfect for a cold November night!

Draught at Mikkeller Bar.
Dark brown coloured with a small beige head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel and dried fruits with notes of spices.
Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel, dried fruits, spices, hops and berries.
Sweet finish.

Draft. A black beer with a brown shine - seemingly a bit murky with a thin tan head. The aroma has strong notes of ginger and cardemomme as well as medium notes of roasted malt and chocolate. The flavor has strong notes of spices - ginger and cardemomme, combined with medium notes of malt and chocolate, leading to a dry spicy finish.
dark brown, small yellow head. 3  aroma of roasted grains, licorice, 7. Flavor is strong licorice, lots of licorice, roasted grains, licorice. 7 .

Dark brown beer with medium and beige head. Aroma is untypical, but not bad and it slightly reminds to Haanbryggeriet Norwegian Wood. Roastiness, junipers, hint of alcohol and slighlty sweet and sour aroma. Flavour continues naturally from the aroma, roastiness, some liquirice and sourness, junipers and spicyness; when the beer is warmer flavour is more balanced. Overally, nuancees are hard to describe, meaning weird. Full bodied and smooth to drink. Hard to rate, maybe too weird, but still there are something unique and interesting; I think I have to taste another bottle.

Tap @ Mikkeller Bar, Cph.
Pours deep brown, bordering on black. Small, creamy, beige head. Aroma has lots of freshly ground ginger, light chocolate malty goodness, coriander, some cardemum peeping through. Really Christmas in a glass. Medium carbonation, great dry and light creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is really delicious. There is an oaky, barnyardy hint in there behind lots of dark chocolate, ginger, some cinnamon, light cardemum. Long malty and spicy dry finish. Really lovely beer.

Bottled. Deep reddish brown colour. Thin but creamy head. Warm aroma of sweet rye bread, some malt syrup, and light fruitiness. And the the spices: lots of cardamom-like aromas, menthol, licorice and other medicinal/herbal stuff hard to define. A touch of chocolate in the finish. Sweet maltiness gives quite enjoyable balance and hides the alcohol. Full bodied, low carbonated and syrupy texture. Truly a beet that gives you strength.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2012 500ml bottle from AlkoBatch 526, brygget 030810
I tasted a draught version of this last year and sadly the bottled version is nowhere near it. Taste is somewhat raw and too spicy, needs at least few months of aging. 7-4-7-3-13

Re-rated on 22.12.2012, vertical with Stones version.
Batch 526, brygget 030810 - Pours dark brown, almost black with a smooth white head. Aroma of strong spicy notes, raisins, plum, ripe fruits, hops and yeasty notes. Taste is smooth, spicy and malty with licorice, some hints of dark ripe fruits, yeast and plum. Finish is smooth and spicy with caramely malty notes. Nice, certainly a lot better than 2 years ago. Reminds me a bit of Nøgnes #100 with a lot of spices.

Bottle @ the NØ brewery, Grimstad, from the first batch of the second edition of this collaboration Christmas beer. Pours a near-black, deep brown body with a big tan head, just as a sturdy Christmas brew is supposed to. Aroma is molasses, nuts, dark malts and some herbal sweetness (the California white sage?) and hints of cinnamon and muscat. Very Xmas-y indeed. Taste is licorice, clove or muscat, hints of coffee, brown sugar and abundant, full maltiness. Very nice. Palate is smooth, yet filling - this has more or less all the qualities of a stand-out Christmas beer. A great beer from this collaboration between three top international breweries.

Nose is cinnamon, unknown spices. Taste is all spices and some malty chocolate. Cinnamon, christmas spices. Alcohol is evident. Reminds me of some of the Anchor Xmas brews. Cant drink a ton of this but it works on a nice cool fall night.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Bottle. Pours a nice dark brown with decent tan coloured head. Some lacing. Big ginger aromas supported by toasted malt and a hint of alcohol. Flavours of toasted malt up front. Spicy and bitter finish. Oily mouthfeel. Really enjoyed this one,

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2017 Bottle, september 23rd 2016. Black body with a tanned head. Aroma is malty with herbs, raisin, juniper. Taste is bittersweet, roasty, juniper, licorice. Christmas spiced finish, lovely dark malt aftertaste. A very nice brew.

Bottles from Frank Smiths and Capones. Pours turbid brownwith clingy off-khaki head. Nose is dark malty, fruity and spicy, with cinnamon, malt, hops, and berry notes. Tastes malty, with some berry, plus spice, nuts, and very complex. I liked this version a tad better than the Stone, but theres no way in hell I could tell them apart side-by-side.

Dirty brown pour with floaties, nice ring though. Aroma is minty, spicy (cloves, cinnamon) and candied cherries. The taste reminds me of gin. It is also vinous. The alcohol is quite apparent which isnt a bad thing. Full palate, soft carbonation. Its not the best beer Ive had but it is unique and very fun to drink. Nice sipper.

Cask@Håndverkerstuene. Black with a thin layer of big airy o/w bubbles. Odd aroma of salty liquorice, cough syrup, evergreen, some alcohol, a bit soapy. Sounds terrible, but isnt. Coffee comes through in the flavour, bitter spices. Well balanced, if a bit on the dry side. A bit flat, but its cask. Medium bodied. Actually quite chuffable. This was wierd. Definitely christmasy. Not as wierd as Underlig Jul/Peculiar Yule though. I enjoyed it.

Bottle: Pours an amber color with a nice white head. the nose is very spicy with lots of juniper and malts. Nearly medicinal with a fruity and spicy flavor and a thick sweet yeasty body to accompany. A little out there, but it works for the holiday beers. The finish comes together and its still quite quaffable, its just that middle part that gets in the way for me.

500mL bottle.  Pours a viscous, murky dark mahogany with a small, dense and persistent tan head.  Reasonably complex aroma as expected from a beer with so many ingredients, the strongest being dried fruit followed by juniper and a hint of the caraway.  A bit of roast in the flavour, quite sweet, a little spicy and with low bitterness.  The alcohol is noticeable on the nose and palate.  Full bodied and quite thick, very creamy with a fruity and spicy finish.
UPDATED: OCT 5, 2014 a touch more spice and less hops than the stone version.  nearly identical and just about as awesome.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2012 Tap @ Olutravintola Pikkulintu. Rated on 5.12.2009.
Deep red colour with a creamy head. Very spicy aroma with notes of gingerbread, coriander and licorice. Rich flavor has the same elements with caramel, nuts and wood. Full bodied, oily and smooth texture. Very well balanced and pleasant for the holiday season. 9-4-8-4-16 4.1
500 ml bottle, batch #526, bottled 3.8.2010, BBE 3.8.2015.
Pours a very dark brown colour with very low on transparency. Small off-white head. Aroma of strong anise, pepper and licorice. Strong flavour of cough drops, salty licorice, pepper, anise and nuts. Some light sweet and ripe berries as well. Medium bodied, very smooth mouthfeel. Strong and long finish of sweet ripe fruits, anise and licorice. What a lovely spicy soup. Ages well, it seems. Could use some bite, which the tap version had. 8-4-8-4-16 4.0

My Bottom Line:
Raisins, juniper and spiced bread notes adorn this full-bodied yet effervescent dessert brew.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam floats atop the cloudy dark brown. There is too much yeast in the bottle to my liking.
-Mild citrusy tartness is found in the last half of each sip.
-The finish is not cloying at all, which often happens in these Christmasy spiced ales.
-The yeast gets in the way of the flavor even if you are careful not to include any in your glass.

Bottle.
Deep dark brown body with tan head. Lots of spice notes on the aroma and taste, medium body and moderate carbonation, alcohol hidden and easy enough to drink.
Pours a deep brown with a smooth tan head. Nose is spicy, sage, ginger, toffee and caramel. Silky mouth feel, sweet malt, bitter chocolate with lots of spices.
