pours a very dark brown with ruby hues...nearly black...opaque...with a thick tan head...very nice lacing and retention.  aroma is spicy...nutmeg, cinnamon?...also a bit like a spicy cologne...sage evident with some spruce, subtle sweet vanilla, nutty, hint of citrus...warming.  flavor is sweet at first followed by spice and roastiness...hint of chocolate and chestnuts come through a bit.  finish is earthy and spicey/sprucey...lingers.  motufeel is thick and lively...silky.  thoroughly enjoyed this one!

bottle found in the clearance rack. pour is a dark earthy brown with a thick one finger head. aroma has sage, spice, juniper, nuts, and some sweetness. mouth feel is medium and has plenty of carbonation. flavor is really heavy on the sage(almost too much so), spices, juniper, sweetness, and a hit of rye bitterness.
Not a great beer at all, not terrible, I wouldnt buy it again. I was expecting substantially more. this one had a weird metallic taste that the previous incarnation did not have. it was really bad.

Super dece beer. Poured with a tan, fine foamy, head and a little lace. Color is an almost opaque, mahoganey brown. Aroma is malty, spicey, dark ripe fruits. Flavor is like aroma but the spices come out more - can definitely pick out the sage and juniper; chestnuts are muted. Body and carbonation are perfect for the style: round full, fine aggresive but not overdone bubbles. Finish is like flavor, very well balance and short to medium long. Easy drinking beer. Could have another. Be real good with hearty meals.

Bottle. It looks quite lovely in the glass, its almost clear, chestnut-colored, and a finger-thcik, creamy, beige head sits patiently on top, leaving some lacings as the glass empties. The aroma has a nice anise-like start, guess its the sage playing. A juniper-like touch also chimes in, along with roasted malts, dired fruits, caramel and little touch of molasses or some other dark sugar. Its full-bodied and almost sticky sweet, but with enough alcohol and bitterness to cope with it. At least as a beer for the darker, colder months. Theres licorice and juniper berries too in the flavor, and a fine bitterness to finish it. Loved drinking this one last Christmas, so much I obviously forgot rating it, and was delighted to hear it will return this year. 100711

picked this up on the discount rack at sun devil.  3/13/2010

opaque. reddish orange dark brown with a soft strangely colored orange head. lots of spotty lacing. 

very herbaceous and spicy nose... brown sugar, ginger, roasty grain, sweet pine/juniper and earth also show up. 

chocolate finds its way into the flavor profile... along with black bread, molasses, orange peel, ginger, some skunky noble hops, brown sugar and a lightly bitter finish. it is a bit messy with a bunch of different components but it seems to work... much like fruit cake does.

its medium-full bodied, rich and creamy yet crisp and highly drinkable. 7/4/7/4/16/3.8

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2010 piney, juniper, spicey aroma...caraway & flowery? Wow, couldnt be a more complex aroma. I am still pondering it.  Dark and a bit bready chocolate like Old Rasputin. Wow...very rich bodied palate.  Sweet and spice taste, and smoooooth as can be. Lively yet not carbonic, and creaminess? How the hell did they make this beer? Tasted from the bottle @ 60°F.

Christmas in July, gotta love it. After looking over my notes for this one I had a one word description for it, SPICE!! It was definitely one of the tastier/spicier beers that I tried that night. The color was dark with a white foam head that quickly disappeared. I could really pull the roasted flavors out of this one.

This bottled brew from a rating party poured a medium sized head of foamy finely sized dark brown colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a very hazy dark brown colored body. The mild aroma was spicy malty and sage. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a acidic aftertaste. The strong flavor contained notes of sour and spices. An OK brew just nothing special.

Pours huge orangy-tan head. Huge amounts of bubbles coating inside of glass. Aroma is not the normal beer. Perhaps the Sage? Flavor is blended very well. Hints of the juniper dont clash with the malts. Rye not as huge as lots of other rye beers. Almost like a sweet peach. Sort of a perfumy aftertaste. Slightly thicker than average body. Very nice. Too bad its soooooo expensive $10/500ml btl!!

Bottle 500ml. @ home.[ Trade by yngwie ]. Clear dark red brown color with a average to large, creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, fruity - berry, pumpkin - cinnamon - nutmeg, maybe ginger also, light roastead, nutty notes. Flavor is light heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a long duration, anis - juniper, berries, spicy, sweet. Body is medium, texture is oily - syrupy and sticky, carbonation is soft. Not my liking to sweet and strange spicy .. [20100531]

Bottle. Red dark amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is ginger, juniper, chestnuts, caramel. Flavour is sweet, ginger, juniper, malt, hop, yeast, caramel, dried fruits, spices. Full body. Nice beer.
Warm and malty with lovely roasted chestnut notes, balanced by the almost citrus juinper and savory sage. Really rich, lovely, warm beer.

Bottle; remember not really liking the previous version made at I believe Stone.  Poured a chestnut/auburn/brown color with a slow rising, but good sized tan head.  Aroma of nuts, fruit, herbs, bread, caramel and medicinal.  Still not really digging this one that much, although I probably like it a bit better if memory serves me.  A bit too much of the sage, turns it into a medicinal tasting beer.  This one seems to have a bit more caramel, with probably a bit more alcohol and fruit as well.  Better than expected, but nothing Id really want very frequently.
Distinctive nutty, malty and alcohol-sweet aroma, with noticeable sage and caraway-rye flavors. Undertones of yeast, banana, and a creamy mouthfeel. Deep, blood-red in color. Tasty.
Brown color with a large head.  Strong aroma of sage.  Very malty and bready flavor.  Full of chestnuts and sage.  Juniper doesnt stand out too much.  Delicious.

Bottle.  Pours clear dark brown with a medium, creamy tan head, fair retention.  Aroma is medium sweet caramel and nutty malt, spicy hops, sage, juniper, light caraway, light fruity esters, and light phenols.  Flavor is medium sweet, nutty malt, sage, juniper, alcohol, caraway, light hop bitterness.  Medium body, moderate carbonation.

500 ml bottle from Belmont Party Supply.  Tried side-by-side with the same collaboration brewed at Stone.  Pours a really dark brown, opaque, with mahogany-red highlights and a fucking massive tan head that leaves a ton of lacing.  The head is out of control on this one.  This one has a nicer aroma than the Stone-brewed counterpart, with notes of caramel malts, peppermint, ginger, licorice, cola, cherries, holly, juniper, cola, Dr. Pepper, and pine.  I could smell this beer all day.  Flavor of the same holiday spices, juniper, ginger, cherries, pine, brown sugar, caramel malts, pepper, cola, nuts, chocolate, and syrup.  This is awesome, start to finish.  Every time I pull it up to my mouth Im excited.  The alcohol is hidden, the spices and sweetness come through and balance each other out, and the body is nice.  Medium-bodied, with gentle carbonation and a sticky mouthfeel.  This is better than the Stone-brewed version; I havent found the JP one but cant wait to do so.  Awesome beer.

This was a treat. Aroma was top-notch. Tasted like a nut brown ale crossed with an abbey dubel. Very spicy and smooth. Couldnt hardly taste the alcohol at 8.5% which was a plus. You could definitely taste the chestnuts, sage and caraway. the juniper berries added a nice touch to it. Overall this was an awesome brew and I would highly recommend it if you find it.

Bottle from Canals. First off, I found this to be one interesting Pumpkin Ale. Pours a thick brown with a nose of Cinnamon, pumpkin and spice. The flavor was pretty much the same. However, it had a dry sweet finish. Not overly sweet.

Very Good for its style.

50cl bottle.   Im wondering how the exact recipe differs in this version compared to the Stone version, as they both use the same yeast strain from what I have heard.   Water is the main suspect here, but I would guess that base malt is probably different, with Nogne using marris otter in all of their beers from what I have heard the brewer say.Then of course you are brewing on a much smaller system in this case...Well, the beer pours a dark brown color with a medium sized beige head with creamy texture and good retention.   The aroma has a punchy rye bread character with juniper and sage being immediately apparent as well.   Almost like a creamy, spiced coffee cake with a dusting of cocoa powder.   The sage in particular strikes a nice chord, but maybe thats just because its my local ingredient.   I just love walking into a garden with sage bushes in it.   The flavor starts out with some caramel sweetness and chocolate cake, and transitions in to a dryer chocolate finish that is also a little nutty and earthy.   Rye shows in the finish, and the spices come through all around.   Soft, almost moussey carbonation.   I like how this starts out a little on the sweet side and then the finish gets dry with spiced chocolate.   Unique spice profile for sure, and seems a little punchier than last year.
Pours dark reddish brown.   Molasses, roasted malts, caramel, dark chocolate, little licorice, spices,.

Hazy brown.  Spicy, chocolatey and cherryish aroma is quite complex with herbal, slightly medicinal quality.  Chocolate and some toast with the fruit a little further back on the palate.  Some astringency from the spice.

Finally decided to purchase the bottled (exactly as pictured) at Greens on Ponce De Leon. Fluffy head at first, but the head recedes quickly. The appearance is rather nice; the dark brown, nearly black body looks wonderful. The beer is almost opaque, but seems to me to be rather translucent i.e. some light is poking its way through. A little bit of head retention would have forced me to give this a perfect score for appearance. Juniper is nice and strong as it was in the last collaboration amongst these brewers. The sage is immediately noticeable. In my mind, the sage and juniper dominate the aroma, and mix very well together. Some sweet aromas are popping through, but it is very arduous to detect them.  I would like have this side-by-side with the previous years collaboration. I feel this one has a different malt character to it. Caramel malts are poking through, or so it seems. The juniper and sage are definitely there, and are offering an extremely nice spice flavor. I feel as though the malt sweetness and a touch of hop bitterness are what is different in this years (I guess I should say last years) collaboration. The more obvious malt presence seems to give it a "richer" texture. Shit, I think I am detecting some roast flavor in this as well. Hmmm...I like the texture a little bit better than the previous collaboration, but for some reason I am thinking I enjoyed the other one a little bit more. I enjoy the sage and juniper, but it doesnt feel completely right for some reason. Still, a damn fine spice and herb beer.
500ml bottle. Pours dark brown color body with brown/beige head. Aroma of nuts, hops, malt and raisin. Taste of slightly smoked malt, spice and nuts.

Bottle. Pours thick opaque dark brown with nice lasting but small soft tan head. Spicy aroma is warm and inviting. Nutmeg, cinnamon, clove, juniper. Flavors are also very spicy with a very creamy mouthfeel. Dry spicy finish is like sucking on a cinnamon stick. Finishes like a spiced gin. Has character.

bottle at Fort Wayne tasting - The aroma is very spicy and the sage is quite noticeable.  Theres also some malt and alcohol.  The strong flavor is sweet malt, sage, spice, and perhaps some subdued pine.  Its medium to full bodied and very enjoyable.

500mL Bottle, purchased at Village Bottle Shoppe - West Lafayette, IN. Pours an intensely viscous dark brown-amber, with a fine, perfuse carbonation. Interesting texture. Very silky and smooth, super-creamy. Aroma is a strong gust of sage dust and juniper. I find the combination to smell a bit of male deodorant and like fake fragrances found in many cleaning products. The flavor is a subtler version, with a rather wet, but not sticky, palate. Somehow, it tastes a bit like a ginger barleywine, but with an amplified edge of sage. Unlike the Stone version, I feel like I can parse the sage, which comes up front, from the juniper, which shows in the back end of the palate. Interesting, but still maybe not me.

Bottle thanks to footbalm. Pours a cloudy brown/red color with a large white head. The aroma is complex;  sweet hops, fruity, nutty and spicy as well. The flavor is nice; sweet dominant nutty flavors, roasted and rich malts, spices. Different and unique.

Really jumped out as a big belgian with some more subtle spice notes. Pour is black with a big froathy pale brown head. On the nose the belgianess jumps out but in the mouth you can pick up the juniper and chestnuts on the lingering alchol finish. Well made and slightly out of the ordinary though it is what it is a strong dark belgian ale.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a large foamy light brown color. Nose is dark fruits, mostly plums and apples, with a light dusty note. Palate is fizzy cola, fairly dry. Flavor is pears and plums with a cola flavor and more mustyness.

Bottle. Dark brown beer with a big tan head. Caramel and dried fruit aroma with spice. Caramel/toffee flavor with spice and light cocoa. Medium bodied. Toffee/caramel lingers with spice, cocoa, and sweet malt.

Turbid brown color with a thin beige head.  Big alcohol nose with spice and hair spray.  Warm, almost smokey flavors with sage, juniper and other spices and caramel sweetness.  Big, malty beer with lots of spices and hot alcohol.
Pours red-brown with a tan head. Aroma-winter green, minty, herbal, malty. Taste- spruce, earth, herbs, mouthwash, wintergreen, chocolate. Weird but good.
WOW! Notes of damn near every fruit in the nose of this one! Aroma is fresh cane sugar and kola nut. Pours a cola brown with head that goes away. The juniper really works in this one! Finish clean.
Poured a murky brown color with a tan head.  Yeasty spicy aroma with some chocolate malt notes.  Dry chocolate flavor with a very long spicy finish.  Dry finish and warming.  Light to medium bodied.

A: Fairly similar to the previous version in that its a dark brown with some reddish highlights and a tan colored head.

S: The sage seems to be the most dominant of the flavorings in this beer. The juniper is also quite present and overall the beer just has a very "spicy" feel to it. There is a bit of sweetness hiding in there as well.

T: Despite the nose, the flavor is a little more restrained in terms of the spices. The rye does lend its version of spice to the beer, and the sage is still there as well. A nice sweetness and a mild (hop) bitterness.

M: Fairly full bodied with moderate carbonation.

D: Like the Stone brewed beer before it, this one is good, but "different". I enjoy it for the creative ingredients and being able to make a pretty decent beer, but definitely one of those winter time only beers.

500 ml bottle from Princetons.  Very dark brown pour with a big tan head.  Aroma is full of spices, I cant really pick out the individual ones but it definitely has a "holiday spice" feel to it.  Mouthfeel is chewy and flavor is sweet with those same spices and it ends in a delightfully flavorful finish with a hint of chocolate.  This beer really embodies a holiday ale.

500 mL bottle from the Best Damn Beer Shop I think. I thought I missed this one earlier in the season. The appearance is a deep chestnut brown with a thick medium brown head. A lot deeper then I remember Stones take. The juniper berries jump out first to the nose followed by coriander, sage, and pine-sol. The flavors start with a full rich malt with the juniper hitting the sides to push the beer forward, sage and pine follow to provide a really full mouth.. Some dried cranberries as well.  A little better then I remember the first rendition. I am most excited about JPs soured version if the rumors are true!

Thanks Chuck.  The beer pours to a deep black mahogany/ruby body with a thin but coating off-white head.  The aroma is quite balanced.  I never would expect that sage, chestnuts, and juniper berries would work together.  The sage comes off sweet and blended with the juniper smells almost like thyme and oregano.  The flavor seems pretty chocolate-like with a nice sweet herbal compound.  The finishing flavor of the beer seems to have some nuttiness which could likely only be the chestnuts.  The palate is kind of dry stout like.

Very dark Ruby almost brown pour w/ a short dense tan small bubbled head w/ perfect lacing.  Full well coated and lightly creamy palate.  Big aroma tons of fresh sage a light juniper berry - fresh & bright light sweet caramel underneath and a bit of an earthy note.  Theres a light nuttiness in the aftertaste that I might not have placed as nuts had I not read the description.  Theres also a hint of something that comes through as chocolate in the aftertaste as well but Im not sure that its chocolate. An original taste & delicious.

50 cL bottle. Pours hazy dark brown with a thick off-white to tan head, Aroma is dark spiced, ginger and cinnamon. Hard roasted malt too. Sweet, ginger fruity and dry spiced. Citric and dry into the finish. Dry and citric lasting impression. Too spiced for my liking

500ml - Initial aroma is strong spices followed by roasted dark malts with a touch of hops.  Flavor is doughy chocolate cookies with holiday spices on top.  The JP yeast shows in the finish.  Palate is soft, creamy and spicy.  A very tasty and well balanced holiday brew.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2013 I really believe Nogne O churned out the best holiday ale Ive ever had.  Pours a fairly deep brown and produces a large head.  Tastes of juniper and just the right amount of spices--perhaps a bit of nutmeg, ginger, cloves and maybe cinnamon--this stuff tastes like Christmas. Wonderful beer that, without hesitation, Id take even over my preferred holiday ale, the Great Lakes Christmas Ale. EDIT: After drinking Nogne Os second iteration of this brew, Im downgrading my rating.  I still really love this mahogany christmas ale, but find the juniper berry component a bit overpowering.  It presents an evergreen aspect that, unlike in a piney IPA, comes across as somewhat Vaseline-like initially, although the aftertaste seems more balanced.  I still like it, and it is definitely among the best holiday ales Ive had, but it isnt worthy of the high 4.4 rating I initially gave it back in 2008/2009.

500 ml bottle. Dark amber body with a nice, dense beige head. Well pronounced aroma of sage, ginger, brown sugar, caramel, citric fruit and pine. Flavor is sweet malty, caramel, lots of sage, more spices, dry fruit and a well-balanced bitterness. A pleasant bitterness is also dominating the finish together with warming alcohol and more sage. A smooth and well-balanced beer with lots of interesting flavor. This was sampled together with the Stone version, witch also is very nice. This version is considerable darker, and has more dominating spice flavors, still not to much.

Bottle.  A lush dark brown to black color with a creamy light brown head.  Nicely spiced with smooth chocolate an malts.  It has an almost creamy texture with a bold yet not aggressively spiced flavor and aroma.  It is extremely well balanced and a great drinking beer.

(500ml bottle, courtesy of ilovedarkbeer)  Pours a hazy amber body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of caramel, pine, allspice, ginger, and clove.  Flavor of caramel malt, pine, ginger, clove, cinnamon, brown sugar, and allspice.

THOUGHTS: Had this on Christmas day and it was great. Very Christmasy. It had a very unique aroma and flavor. Hid alcohol just enough. The part that was noticeable added to its Christmasiness. It was like an even better Arctic Circle Ale.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a very dark crimson and looked nearly brown in the glass with red highlights. It had and average to large, tan head that kept a nice sheet and left fair lacing. The aroma was moderate caramel malt; with a hint of chocolate; pepper, licorice, cola, spices, cherry cola and spruce. The initial flavor was sweet, lightly bitter and acidic; while the finish was rather sweet and lightly bitter with a fairly long duration. There was juniper, spices, toffee, nutty manlts, more spices, more fruit, pine (but not pine hops) like spruce, licorice, pepper, cola; and once the yeast was added there was a little more nutty malts and slight chocolate. The medium to full body was sort of silky and then rather dry with soft, yet tingly carbonation and a dry and slightly alcoholic finish.

Special holiday ale enjoyed on 2-14-2010... its a holiday, but I dont think it was the one the beer was intended for.  Regardless the beer still has the holiday feel to it.  The sage and the juniper really come through on this one, very fresh smelling and very festive.  The flavor comes off with the same notes, but combined with a helping of caramel malt, roasted candy sugar and nutmeg.

Frothy biege head on top a misty brown pour aroma earthy spice bit of pepper flavour spicy chestnut juniper berries bright flavoured ale finish smooth with bright flavours good malt and smooth bitter not bad

Had this side by side with the Stone one. It was a bit sweeter and I think would have benefited from a little bit more bittering hops. Spices are pretty nice though with the sage and chestnuts being a bit more pronounced that in the Stone. Decent holiday ale.

Pours gently with a smooth, soft layer of foam and considerable lacing.  Chocolate aromas rise off the beer, with a nutty backing quality that makes this beer smell inviting and warm.  Palate is absolutely excellent.  The alcohol isnt hot, the chocolate and spices come through brilliantly, and mouthfeel is full and the finish is long and nutty.  Its a really smooth spiced ale, with a lot in common with the palates of better milk stouts.  Nice caramel notes towards the finish in addition to a heavy dose of cocoa and semisweet chocolate.

Pours brown with a tan head.  The aroma is berry, spice, mint, and dark fruit.  The flavor has some roast, caramel, cinnamon, and nutmeg, all balanced well with bitterness, and the finish is slightly sour.  The mouth feel is very smooth and creamy.

I am just realizing the concept behind this beer so had to check my last rating of version one from stone. This version seems to be much more dependant on the juniper berries as last years was much more hop dominant. Distinct yeast presence gives the flavor a wildness that is a little more pronounced than I remember as well. Fruity finish and sweetness that lasts a while. Very seasonal so dont hold on to this one for too long. A uniquely spicey berry and pine aroma. Very prominent with that berry here which I wish just a tad toned down but this is a pretty entertaining beer nonetheless.

How do you pronounce Nogne? Great aroma of Thanksgiving and Christmas waifs up from the bottle. Absolutely beautiful dark mahogany with a big tan head. Flavor is complex with sweet malt and molasses up front with a bunch of spice in the middle followed by some hop bitterness. Finishes clean and crisp. One of my top Christmas beers even though its February.

Pours chestnut brown with a large rocky tan head.  The aroma is very spiced up with toasted malt, hints of maple syrup and brown sugar, but the spice offsets the sweetness and it seems balanced.  The spices arent what Im used to having, so Im not sure which stands out more, but it is powdery and earthy.  Medium / full body that has some slickness and has frothy carbonation.  The flavor starts with the aroma traits, but the malt is more prevalent to balance out the spices and chestnut shows through  especially on the finish.  There is some noticeable alcohol, but it is integrated well with the other flavors.  The finish is dry and spiced.  An interesting and enjoyable beer.

Bottle courtesy of tarheels86 - thank you sir!  Dark maroon color with a thin off white head that settles quickly to leave scant lacing.  Aroma of pumpernickel and rye breads.  Taste starts as a corned beef on rye and progresses to birdseed.  But in a good way.  Interesting, and slightly experimental, but not extreme.

Sampled on 1/2/2010. This ale pours a dark brown color from a 50cl bottle. Medium sized white foamy head with decent lacing. The aroma is juniper, caraway, dark fruit and sweet. A medium bodied spiced ale. The malts are dark fruit and sweet, nutty and spicy. The hops are earthy and floral. Nice carbonation. Hints of chocolate and banana. Nice holiday Ale. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Deep brown pour with a thick tan head.  The nose is really great.  Bright herbal/spicy nose with loads of rye and caraway as well as a heavy dose of juniper.  There is a bright minty component as well that works really well.  Light date fruitiness and a bit of gingery spice as well.  The flavour is quite a bit sweeter and richer than the Stone brewed version.  There is a bit less of the spicy rye component but there is more fruity malt complexity.  Great stuff.

Pours dark mahogany with purple-red highlights and a tan head.  Sweet aroma with quite a bit of plum and vinous notes, as well as cola, bready, nutty yeast, and cardamon.  Flavor is a bit spicier, with cinnamon, juniper, clove, and cardamon notes on a bready, nutty, and fruity backbone.  Soft carbonation and a bitter finish.  Good stuff.

500ml bottle from K&L Redwood City.  Pours dark-reddish brown with a thick light beige head and excellent lacing.  Aroma seems a bit overspiced, with sage, juniper, ginger, and allspice jumping out at you.  Also lots of sweet caramel malt evident.  Flavor is rich but very well-balanced, and surprisingly the spices dont overwhelm.  Sweet caramel malt and molasses, roasted chestnuts, and all the same spices noticeable in the aroma.  Fairly full body with a smooth and creamy mouthfeel and appropriate carbonation level.  This is definitely better than last years Stone incarnation.  A great winter warmer.

Bottle. Pours a hazy, dark brownish ruby colour with a creamy tan head that lasts well. Complex nose is spicy and a little sweet with notes of chocolate, caramel, pepper, aniseed, cola and ginger in addition to the noticeable juniper, sage and caraway. The chestnuts are more noticeable in the flavour as well as notes of ginger, caramel, aniseed, juniper berries and caraway. Thick, creamy mouthfeel with fairly low carbonation and a lingering spicy finish. Very enjoyable winter ale, was surprised I enjoyed it as much as I did; these three breweries really pulled it off.

500ml bottle. 

Pours a dark red/brown color. Aroma is sweet caramel, toffee, with plenty of spices. Flavor is a nice smooth, of malts, spices, ginger - pepper. Touch of chocolates. Bitter finish, lasting spice notes. A mightly fine beer, and a perfect companion for a long, cold winter night.

Pours dark brown with thick off white head. Aroma is very spicy, definitely can smell the juniper and chestnut. Flavor has a lot more spice but its well balanced with a rich creamy mouthfeel. Definitely get more juniper. A well made beer.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2010 500 ml bottle

The second of three releases this is on par with last years release.  I look forward to the final contribution to the series to see if the one sitting in Dexter lives up to its previous two counterparts.  Check this out while it is still on the shelf.  Despite being a little on the pricey side it is worth the cost even if you only buy a single bottle.

Aroma / Appearance - The nice off-white half finger head lived for a few minutes atop the maroon base.  Infused with a black darkness it glowed in the firelight.  Yeast, cherry, nutmeg, and junipers give this a kick that makes one feel as if they are under a Christmas tree.  It does pack a punch so be prepared.

Flavor / Palate - Juniper and sprig starts the show but before long it turns into a completely different beast.  Licorice and anise come along for the ride.  There is a slightly medicinal tinge to the finish that is distracting.  Otherwise this is solid, well rounded, and it was a disappointment when the bottle finally kicked.  If I did have another bottle I would probably give it another six months to mellow out before opening it.

It is interesting how different this beer is from the one brewed at Stone - the hops are definitely more subdued, allowing the other spices and herbs to become more prominent - the nose is loaded with sage and juniper - the chestnuts are very potent in the flavor, and the sage really produces a minty, cooling quality on the tongue - juniper sits on top of moderate caramel maltiness - a touch of tartness on the back end, and some roasted nut quality - lingering sage and mint - much more subtle than the Stone version, but still full of flavor - I like it!

An Epiphany classic. In bottle from Beertopia. A rich, thick spiced beer. I especially enjoyed the thick palate. A good amount of chocolate flavor, but not drying. Fruity and spicy as well - very nicely done. I started thinking how it would be good on pancakes and over ice cream, and then decided that nothing could make it better.

500. Pours a nearly opaque mahogany with some nice creamy dun colored head for a while, then absolutely nothing. Leggy and still. Emperor, the juniper is strong with this one, I can sense it. Lord, you can almost feel it--its like midichlorians rampaging through your nostrils. Juniper and anise all over the nose. Its like a ginger snap martini with no vermouth. Creamy, thick, sticky, nearly still body. Anise, ginger, roast, a little coffee, and tons of juniper on the mid-palate. Long dry finish with lots of tingling spice from the yeast and the juniper. DId I mention the juniper? ooof.

In the bottle from Beertopia. Pours dark sepia to black with a thick sustained dark beige head. Has an intense aroma of spruce/ juniper. This pours like motor oil. A super thick beer with an astounding body. Full mouth with grape flavors and lots of spruce. Finishes with a mild roastedness and some chocolate toward the end. Now this is exactly what I expect from a Christmas beer.
Smells of brown malt and sage. Color is brown and murky, with 2 fingers quickly dissipating head. Medium to high carbonation, finish is sweet.
Bottle brought to Pauls new decade tasting. Hazy brown pour with a slight tan head. Spice bomb, some nut and juniper notes. Very enjoyable. Why this is a seperate rating? Still ISO stone version.

The Dan Journal #321.  Tasted 1/18/10.  500ml bottle.  Dark with an opaque brown hue.  Finger width of khaki head.  Wow, big nose!  The juniper jumps out first, followed by the sage and a nutty character.  Maple and rustic bready malts.  Rather full bodied with a lot of varying spices.  Solid malt note, but they play second fiddle to the spices.  Definitly nutty.  Good, tart astringency.  Subtle dark esters and a mildly drying rye character.  I sense more juniper in the nose than in the palate.  Good spicy, but the malts shine initially and then the finish is all spicy goodness.  Nice.

Had the previous version of this the year before.  The appearance is a nice deep brown, tan head.  The aroma is juniper berries, nuts, malt.  The flavor is chestnuts, some spicyness, like cinnamon, malty, bready.  The finish is purely spicy, cinnamon and nutmeg in particular. Still a great beer.

Dark brown color with a bit off hazed as it is held to the light. Slow forming, taller, lasting, khaki colored head. Spices and herbs noted in the aromas, especially sage and juniper berries. Some mace and woody cinnamon as well in the nose. Touches of toasted malt in the background. Thick, rich and lush feeling brew. With all the thickness, I am surprised that it does not get cloying. Light sweetness with a slow moving spice that heats up the longer this one sets on the palate. Rich dark sugars and toasted malt mingle in along the way. A bit of white pepper in the finish. LInger is light, with just a bit of residual sugar. A nice winter/holiday ale.

Sample at the Barley Wine beer tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 01/14/10. Dark brown pour with a medium tan head. Aroma of cough drops and malt. Some definite herb and spice character in there, but having trouble picking out what because its just too much. Not kidding about the cough drops; it really smells like eucalyptus. Spicy and malty flavor with a bit of bitterness in the finish.

Sample at the Barley Wine beer tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 01/14/10.  This beer pours a muddy brownish-red color with a medium light beige head that dissipates steadily. Stringy lacing. Aroma of cough drops, spice and berries. Medium body with flavors of tart fruit, spices, malt and nuts. The signature Stone hop profile is not omnipresent. The finish is potpourri spices and fruit, with a toasted nut aftertaste. An interesting collaboration overall, and an above average beer.

Deep and dark gleaming burgundy with light brown head that quickly turns to thin film.  medicinal eucalyptus nose, like cough drops.. with a backdrop of mint chocolate chip ice cream.  Seriously, those words hit the nose nail on the head.    First impressions are a thin, extremely watery overall feel to the beer with light, almost essence-like flavors of mint, chocolate, roasted barley, halls cough drops, and caraway seeds.  The finish has a balancing, crisp, and forward hop presence.  This is an extremely interesting beer...The way the flavors are off in the distance with the medicinal edge subtly not so subtle..what I thought was a watery texture at first really isnt so watery...the body is actually quite medium...its just like a coat of gloss over the medicinal, minty, chocolaty flavors that confuses, yet entices.  Seriously, I dont know what part Stone had in the production of this specific beer...but it could possibly be the best beer theyve had their name on in eons.  I am certainly an opponent of most spices in beer, but every blue moon someone seems to combine the right amount and right kinds of spices to produce something that just plain works.  This is one of those blue moon moments.  I need to try the one with Stone named first...if they used their own yeast as I have read, I guarantee that it sucks and is the perfect proof I need to show the world.

(br-btl bk-lbl, 220z)

hazy-dk-br, ^thick-dense-tan-head, fine-^eff, solid-lacing, med-full body, med-co2.

aroma: ^bright spicy ^sage/juniper dark-fruit(prunes or raisins) syrupy-alchl.

flavor: bright-sage/juniper sweet-dark-fruit T1, §chclt-malt sage/juniper §hop-bitterness §chestnut-astringency(?) §chrrd-malt-astringency T2, sticky spiced-dark-fruit-alchl(like oraung tua in indonesia or some spiced rums) T3, same through.

spices are very strong, and i have a bit of difficulty telling them apart (at least the sage and juniper, and the caraway and chestnuts) because i dont have much experience with them in the context of beer.
this beer makes a very interesting and unique special occasion beer, but not something i would want more than once a year.

Bottle from Whole Foods in Arlington.  An interesting beer to say the least.  Aroma has some berry and sage.  Somewhat dense palate, but very enjoyable beer to keep me warm during the cold winter months.

20100112  500ml bottle from State Line.  I dont know if this is a trend, or a resurgence, or whats up, but add this to the list of very enjoyable spice-herb beers Ive picked up recently.  Maybe its a Scandinavian thing, but there was a hot second about five years ago where it seemed related beers might be gaining some footing (sahti, Heavyweight Jåkeldrickå, others) using spruce, juniper, herbs, etc.  But then that gave way to more mediocre imperial stouts and ipas, and creativity once again went by the wayside.  Well what a coup for one of the biggest offenders (albeit a favorite brewer) in Stone to be one of the few generally available US brewers to get on board.  Now Im just rambling.  Lovely stuff, dark brown, hazed, with lasting tan head.  Aroma is mild and suggests sweetness, almost like an herb tea but with some cocoa notes and mild roasted squash.  Body is a tad heavy and sweet, but definitely not cloying, with a nice woody acidic bitterness on the back of the palate.  Flavor adds some root beer, mint (must be the sage), cool juniper.  Very enjoyable brew, but a bit on the sweet and heavy side all around.  I guess the excuse could be that it it supposed to be a winter beer, but Iike to see a dryer beer more pronounced adjuncts in this case.  That sweetness knocks it a few steps behind some of the more refined beers done in a similar style, such as the Norrebro Old Odense.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2013 Final rating averaged bottle (2010) and keg (2009)
Keg (Pikkulintu, Helsinki, Winter beers 2009)
Deep red, small head. Super-massively gingery aroma. Smooth palate, soft carbonation. Loads of ginger in the taste. Rich roast, sweet and spicy. Too much one-track in the spice. Gimick.
Rerate: 500ml Bottle (Alko Arkadia, Helsinki)
7 RIch sweet spicy ginger aroma.
4 Near-black, small beige head.
6+ Retronasals remarkably chestnutty, but with some ginger too. As it warms, alcohol also comes out, but at 8.5% its not surprising or too offensive. Deep roast predminantly, with a biting bitterness made even more biting by the juniper berries probably.
4 Very full smooth palate, heading towards slimy, crisp carbonation sharpens that up nicely. 
14 Lovely balance compared to last year. Spices reined in to only bold, not silly. And its a special, lets be bold. Nice one.
Rerate: 500ml bottle Brewed 2010, drunk 2013. (7:4:7:5:14+=3.7+)
Did try to form a worm out of the bottle. Lovely dark pour, tan ring head, no persistence. Lovely raisiny aroma, clearly aged, just a gentle minty spiciness. Lovely smooth palate, but nice carbonation. Mellow roast in the taste, touch of dustiness, hint of spice. Feel gives a nice tingle, more from ginger and burntness than the carbonation. Roast becomes fuller and richer after swallowing, its lovely and toasty and roasty. Spicing has almost totally gone, it just subtly complements the rich roast, rather than dominating. Such a smooth succulent palate. Age has done a really good job on this beer - I thought it would.
AGE THIS BEER!

Deep ruby tinted copper coloured body with muddy brown highlights and a dense, tan head that tops the beer very nicely. Aroma of pungent nuts, allspice, cloves and star anise with perhaps some toffee or burnt sugar too. Very full-bodied; Strong assertive spice flavours with nuts, dates, toffee, raisins, prunes and even spruce tucked in. Aftertaste shows a good sweet character along with a potent and long-lasting spiciness. Overall, a very good and full-bodied beer, perfect for a cold day in Winter. Overall, a very well made beer - definitely worth trying if you can find it! I sampled this 50 cL bottle purchased for US$9 at Whole Foods in Clarendon (Arlington), Virginia on 08-January-2010, sampled two days later at home in Washington.

16.9 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a fluffy tan head.  Nose is brown sugar and rye bread with contrasting sage and juniper.  Medium to full body with a tang.  Taste is caramel, cocoa and caraway with creamy oat and chestnut.  Finishes with dry spices.  A nice holiday ale that doesnt rely on sugar and spicing.

Bottle, pours a redish muddy brown with a thick tan head that leaves quickly. 
Aroma, initial is very sweet like burnt cotton candy and some flowers. Taste, is very malty as it warms the flowers  spice and  juniper berries come through real strong. I guess this is a good beer for its style but its just not my style of beer.

Beautiful reddish brown muddy/cloudy pour, nice thick tan head dissipated relatively quickly. Aroma is somewhat floral, lots of cotton candy like sugar, molasses, and some spice. Thick mouthfeel, tastes like sweet flowers, way malty. Not my cup of tea.

Dark rusty brown pour produced a caramel colored head with moderate lacing.  Aroma is quite spicy with cinnamon, nutmeg, and pepper along with dark fruit and molasses.  Flavor also exhibits the same spiciness along with roasted chestnuts and brown sugar.  Medium mouthfeel that held the flavor well.  Not bad.

Dark red color on the pour.  Beautiful looking at it through the glass.  Decent head retention.  Slight cloves, corriander, juniper berry, nutmeg, toffee and chocolate on the palate.  Medium bodied beer.  This is very nice.  I smell lots of nutmeg, spices, orange peel, cloves.  Great beer overall.

Bottle. Pours cloudy dark brown with huge tan head that settles. Aroma of licorice and various spices - ginger nutmeg and others, also noticeable pumpkin. Taste is different than you would expect - in a good way. Lots of malt depth but also good amount of hops that I did not detect in the smell, also some light coffee notes.

Bottle: This one seemed salty to me. Arouma of sushi, soy sauce and salt, some nuts, spice and fruits. Taste is dark fruits and pruney, dark toffee malts, salt and pepper. Overall good, but wasnt overawed.
Looks like muddy water with pond scum. A complex taste but not one that turns me on.

.5 liter bottle.  Pours a deep woody brown some lsight haze and a good fluffy head.  Seemed to be slightly different in character than the one brewed at Stone.  Aroma is big in the juniper beery- slight sage, and seemingly very light chsetnuts- good earth, and some slight roasty nutty chocolate malts.  Flavor is earthy, toast, juniper berry, mint, sage, toasted wood, grainy with some nutty chocolate- smooth and moderately sweet- somewhat clean finish with a lot going on in the back of the mouth.  Good.

500 ml bottle from Bev4less. Pours an opaque dark brown color with a medium beige head that slowly fades to a fine ring. The aroma  is spicy with nutmeg, allspice, cedar and cranberries. The flavor is similar to the aroma with a mix of berries and nuts set in nutmeg and allspice backdrop. The palate is full and silky smooth with lively carbonation. The finish is long with lingering spices and a it of sourness. Overall: A very tasty ale.

Bottle at Pauls tasting.  Pours black with a thin white head.  Loads of spices and touches of malt.  Medium bodied, nice mouthfeel but overflowing with spices, heavy on the cinnamon and juniper.  Finishes with a slow spiced bitter and more spice and a light chocolaty bitterness.

So this one was brewed at Nogne so its a new rating?  Well oddly enough it seams to be.  Pours a murky burne body with a white head.  A pure onslaught of spices.  Pine, pine combs, ginger, menthol, juniper, caramine.  Spicy bitter and well spices, what else can i say.  My mouth was refreshed.

0.5L bottle. Pours a brown-amber colored body with a finger-width, creamy, tan head that dissipates quickly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is fairly sweet caramels with a nice spicing and noticable berry, currant smell. Nutty, some yeast, and a bit metallic with a light, almost minty hop. A little bit of maple and chocolate accompanies the caramels too. Flavor is quite nice. Again, there is a good amount of rich, sweeter malts that give off more of a chocolate flavor than the aroma. The nuts are lightly toasted and there is still a touch of maple. All this balances nicely with a good amount of holiday spices and a light berry fruit. Finishes with a lightly smoked chocolate and a woody bitterness. Lingers for a moderate duration after a medium to full, slightly chewy body. Overall, another solid beer from the trio. This one seems a bit sweeter than last years version, but still maintains a balanced spiciness and toasted nuttiness. No complaints here.

Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights and a thin head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is sweet and malty along with sage, berries and a hint of pumpkin - some chocolate?. Flavor is pretty sweet, with some caramel maltiness, spice, juniper berries and pumpkin - again a tinge of chocolate on the back of the tongue. Good holiday brew.
Bottle purchased from half time in Poughkeepsie.  Very similar to the other the other holiday colaberation from this crew... Maybe a but smoother. Juniper berries and chestnuts all up in this grill.

Pours dark reddish brown with khaki head.  Aromas of juniper, chocolate, and some spices. The flavor is a lot more chocolatey than you would expect from the aroma. There is also toasted malt and juniper flavors. Full body with moderate carbonation and a chewy mouthfeel. A really nice winter beer.

This beer pours nearly black with a very large tan head that grows even after the pour.  So pleasant an aroma!  Chocolate, fruit, anise.  Flavor is similar, but even better!  Delicious and just as smooth as silk.  Was surprised to see the ABV as listed and have to question it.  It seems much lower, almost sessionable.   Just so enjoyable.

Bottle @ Ebenezers. Dark mahogany pour with a small beige head. Aroma holds tons of herbal notes, with sage and rosemary dominant. Also notes of carraway, rye, and some nuttiness- very intriguing on the nose. Flavor is similar to the aroma, with lots of sage and increased nuttiness. Awesome stuff, particularly for the style.

Pour is dark mahogany with a thin beige head. Aroma is exceptionally spicy- sage, rosemary, cardamon, clove, nutmeg, while chocolate and roast keep a background profile. The flavor is hugely spicy with loads of sage near the finish.  Flavor is also massively spicy- sage is actually quite huge. A distinct nutty quality makes its way in as well with backgrounds of molasses, caramel, and roast. Palate is thick and viscous with a dry herbal finish. Delicious

Secret Santa bottle. Really pretty dark brown pour with a big tan head. Nice aroma of coffee, juniper needles and roasted malt. More of the same in the flavour but maybe a little dialed up on the juniper and some gentle hops in the finish. The 8.5 ABV is buried deep. Nice Christmas drink.

Bottle: &nbsp Deep brown, heavy burnt caramel hues, large foamy light beige head, very nice lacing. &nbsp Spicy nose, sage is more apparent in this one than the Stone example. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel stands out to me, very thick and viscous. &nbsp So far I think I am liking this one better. &nbsp Seems to be a little bit of Anise in this. &nbsp Reminds me of a lighter in flavor but heavier in body Our Special Ale. &nbsp Has a bit of evergreen or spruce as well. &nbsp Its like a forest with some spices. &nbsp Good body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Could stand to be a touch sweeter. &nbsp Guessing Jolly Pumpkin will be doing next years. &nbsp Interested in seeing how that turns out.
Dark brown crisp and thin pour.  Thin white head.  Herbal and fruity aroma with pine cones and spice.  Loose and dry with hint of chocolate and herbs.  Mostly tasteless and watery.

.5 litre bottle.  The pour on this beer I thought was amazing.  It almost pours like syrup, dense and thick, resulting in a hazy deep brown ale with a luscious, creamy tan head that lasted through three-quarters of the glass and left moderate lace.  Pleasant aroma of malt with some cinnamon and cardamom along with a few vapors of alcohol.  The flavor is malt with some nuts, molasses, cinnamon and cardamom.  The alcohol is well hidden in the flavor.  Mild bitterness at the finish.  Very nice Christmas ale.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2010 Dark brown with giant brown head.  Pumpkin spicey aroma with rich sugary notes.  Taste is also rich with spice and tannic notes and cola in to the finish.  Rating 999 NYE 2009.  Nice, but definitely not highly drinkable with the heavy spice and apparent alcohol.  $9.99/1pt9oz

500 mL bottle from Total Wine in Norfolk, VA.  Muddy brown pour with a thick, creamy tan head.  Interesting aroma that Im not sure I fully am grasping.  I suppose sage jumps out the most along with a hint of roasted malt.  Chocolatey flavor with some spice.  Creamy mouthfeel.  This is really nice and quite unique from anything I have ever tried.

Pours a dark brown with creamy small-medium tan head. Sweet malt, berries, fruit bread, lots of juniper, sage, slightly floral, light spice, & toasted nuts layered in the flavor. Very nice flavored Christmas ale. Creamy mouthfeel, with a very nice amount of carbonation.

.5L bottle pours deep brown with tannish, creamy head.  Big aroma of dark fruits, yeast, bread, and some smoke.  Slight floral notes too.  Extremely smooth body with a great mouth feel.  Ripe berry flavor at the end after a drying on the tongue.  Nice coating in the mouth with some soy.  Alot going on in this one but very good.

500mL bottle.  Pours a murky mahogany with a thick and fluffy khaki head.  Berries and spices abound in the delightful aroma that also features grapefruits, rye bread, vanilla extract, a touch of anise, sage, eucalyptus, and some nuttiness in the background.  Goes down full-bodied, crazily thick & creamy, and very smooth.  The flavor starts with sweet caramel, dark chocolate, some anise, and a touch of vanilla extract.  Juniper berries add a very unique taste.  Sage and mint are present too.  Toasted rye and roasted coffee flavors follow.  There is a subtle, roasty nuttiness underneath.  Mandarin oranges and some grapefruits finish things off with a dryness that hangs around for a bit.  Warming alcohol is present throughout and only adds to the complexity.  A bit different than last years version brewed by Stone (the juniper berries are definitely accentuated this year), but no less impressive.

Bottle at Cardinal 16.9.2009. This is the new edition brewed at Nøgne Ø earlier this summer (as announced at Cardinals Stone Brewing event). 
An off white creamy sparkling head in tops a cloudy (even muddy) dark brown pour. A truly exiting aroma consisting of brown sugar, juniper berries, anis seeds, licorice, roasted nuts and herbs (sage), solvent/band aid. Creamy sweetness gives way to an alcohiloc finish - many of the flavors present during the swallow. Recommended.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2011 50 cl bottle at home. Very dark beer with a nice and lasting beige head. Aroma is roasted malt and different kinds of spices. Flavor is roasted, chocolate, hints of licorice, spices... Very smooth mouthfeel. Some bitterness in the finish. Very nice beer.

I liked this beer, very interesting. Pours a red/amber with a small tan head. 9% is hidden and smooth. Heavy spice aroma. Some roasted malts, with a lot of the spices kicking up as you drink it. I think it is a great holiday beer.

Forgot I had already done the fist of this series last year. This year didnt go much better, though. Bottle from SL. Pour was dark brown in color, almost black? The head was off-white to choco, quite generous with good lacing. The aroma was medicinal, cough drops, various spices, sure juniper works. Flavor followed, a tad medicinal/cough syrupey, some light chocolate/cocoa, birch/cola, a touch of citrus. As with last years, where is JP on this production? Mouthfeel was the highlight here, oily, smooth, better aged than last year too? Meh, still a spice brew.

Bottle from Knightly Spirits. I cracked this brew with great anticipation, seeing the collaboration of such great quality breweries. Pours an amberish brown body with an aroma that envelopes the nostrils with a hspice rack of herbs and sassafrass root. The spice continues in the flavor, where sage, subtle nutmeg, pine sap, coriander, biscuit notes, and an aftertaste of cola all intermingle. Medium carbonation and full body. I loved this, its a great example of a holiday-inspired brew. And I drank it on Christmas night...AFTER church.

From bottle graciously shared by awiseman.  Aroma is most notably herbal.  Pours a deep brown with not much head to speak of.  Tastes like Im chewing on mint leaves and pine needles, as well as the juniper berries described.  Slightly sharp on the tongue with some lingering bitterness.  Not my favorite holiday beer, but quite interesting.  Reminds me of snow falling on pine trees, whatever that means...

Bottle from Keg Liquors in Clarksville, shared with Brothers Eric & Nathan. Pours murks dark brown with thin light brown head. Nose is cooking spice dark ale. Flavor is dry, earthy spices, sage, and nutty brown malt. I really love this change-up in flavor from what Im used to. The sage really does it for me...it really works. Nice beer.

Nogne Os version pours a almost black color with tan head. Big crushed evergreen needle, sage aromas. Smooth medium body. Nutty roasty flavors at first give way to spicy sweet Christmas tree and sage. Finishes on the dry side with Christmas candle spices.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle. Head is initially average sized, creamy/frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is hazy medium to dark orange-brown, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, cookie), lightly hoppy (apricot, grapefruit), with notes of juniper/gin, eucalyptus, oregano, alcohol. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, velvety/creamy texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Interesting evidence that the brewer alone can make a significant difference...Stones version of this recipe was pretty disappointing, mostly in the aroma department.  This one still isnt awesome or anything, but its quite a bit more enticing and enjoyable.  Im looking forward to seeing what Ron will do with this next year.

This ale was sold out at the Norwegian Vinmonopolet during a few days in November. Being away at the time, I really appreciated that my good neighbour Finn H. bought me a bottle. Thanks! 500ml, batch no. 440. Initial yellow-beige head over a slightly unclear, ruby-brown body. Rich Yuletide aroma of spiced juniper. Smooth and mouth filling flavour of dried fruits like prunes mingled with spicy, tart berries added by bready, semi-sweet malts behind. Bitter coffee notes towards the ending along with more bitter berries and fruit. Full bodied and a bit foamy on the swallow. Very nice sipper on a Christmas Day under the polar stars (Tromsø, 25.12.2009).

Bottle from Belmont Party. Poured hazy dark brown color with an average creamy light brown head that lasted with good lacing. Good complex nuts, ginger and spice aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy complex spicy flavor with a medium to heavy herbal sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Complex standout brew for style and better in 2009.
What a great holiday beer. Cola color with a white head. Spicy smell. The flavor is rich, and full of cardamom. Chocolate with great spices. Yum.
Pours mahogany into a snifter. Off-white micro head recedes to skim surface. Juniper and rye aromas. Peppery upfront turning to chestnut in the lasting spice finish.
A terrific Christmas ale on Christmas day.  Aroma of spices like juniper, cinnamon, and sage.  Flavor is sweet and is same as aroma with licorice and malt.

Dark brown pour.  Aroma is loaded with christmas spices, sage, toffee, fruit, cookies.  Flavor is really awesome.  Spices and cookies, toffee, caramel, golden raisins, booze...best holiday beer I have had in a long time.

12 oz. bottle. 9% ABV per the label. Shared with Gabe. Pours an off white head, over a dark brown (SRM 25) body......nose is juniper sweet malt, bit of sage.....taste is tart, gin like, with a lingering alcoholic twinge, combined with a harsh, medicinal, chemical end....mouth feel is medium, as is carbonation.

Thanks to my Secret Santa for sending this collab my way! Id very much enjoyed the 2008 version, and this modest variation is another enjoyable brew. Pours cloudy and almost milky, with an oily scrim of foam on top of a beer that couldve been unearthed from some Viking burial mound. The nose is quite distinctive, with the sage and juniper blending very sharply to give it an almost mentholated quality. Sharper taste becomes quickly apparent, almost as if there is some spruce here as well (which there apparently isnt), and the deep brown is mellowed out by the lovely chestnut taste. Finish is oddly abrupt in its dryness. Overall, a goodern.

[Bottle] Pours a very syrupy, viscous looking burnt caramel with a slowly rising head of khaki bubbles that quickly dissipate. Aroma is sweet and malty, a hint of pumpkin, belgian yeast, some nuttiness and breadiness. Flavor is fairly sweet, some caramel maltiness, not as much for spices as I would have expected, a touch of woodiness, and some black licorice. Decent beer, but I was expecting more.

500ml bottle served in a Tank 7 tulip. Bottle conditioned. Poured a dark brown with about two fingers of tan head. Very fragrant. Juniper, spruce, eucalyptus. Also some dark malt as it warms. Medium bodied. Dark fruit, chocolate malt and more spices in the flavor. Spruce and Juniper. Very long finish of spices. Very interesting beer. If you like Anchor OSA, this would be up your alley. You wouldnt want to make a night of it, but fairly drinkable. Great holiday brew.

Pours an extremely dark chestnut brown color, showing glints of crimson at the edges when backlit. A tall, dense head of spongy, dark tan foam displays excellent retention, sticking around for ages and leaving thick sheets of lacing all over the glass.  The nose is Christmas in a nutshell. Aromas of rich, dry cocoa and warmed caramel are spiced beautifully with roasted chestnuts, fresh juniper, earthy allspice, and brown tea leaves. Hints of minty spruce are also strong and inviting. Flavors are considerably more malty than in the first batch, both cocoa and roasty chestnuts showing considerably more prominently than I recall. Juniper lends that sprucey, minty note, while dark winter spices offer countering, eathen bitterness. A touch of vanilla finishes things off nicely.  The palate is moderately substantive, showing a little bit of creamy roundness up front that transitions into a spicy, drying bitterness on the back end. Id say that I like this Nøgne Ø brewed version a little better than the Stone batch, as it seems a little more balanced and bigger in mouthfeel. Good holiday ale.
500ml bottle.  Really excellent spiced ale.  Im not exactly sure of white sage flavor but I think flavor is mostly juniper with a spicy, almost ginger like finish.

Bottle from Healthy Spirits. Pours dark brown with a massive tan head that lasted quite a while after it almost spilled over the top of the glass. There was a lot of foam in the bottle even after all the liquid was gone. There is certainly some pumpkin and other spices in the aroma and also in the flavor. I am usually not very fond of spicy herbal beers, but this one is actually pretty tasty, although there is a slightly harsh and bitter finish.

Large brown head of dense and creamy bubbles.  Peppermint, cinnamon, menthol and some brown sugar are all present in the mish mosh of aromas.  Color is a very dark crimson brown.  Almost black in color.  Strong roastyness in the flavor with lots more peppermint, spruce and some dark chocolate.  Almost like eating mint chocolate chip icecream.  Finishes spicy with a lingering roastyness and a tad of grittyness.  A decent holiday brew.

reddish brown with thick tan.  low crystal malt sweetness with some herbal notes to the nose.  rather low carbonation.  on first sip, this tastes like a well made irish red ale, once reading the product description the pepper is discernable and adds an interesting flavor, the chestnut is only noticeable in a muted nuttyness that is provides the brew, with the juniper berries being very subtle.  a lot of residual malt sweetness with some english ale type esters.  the alcohol is almost entirely hidden and the 8+ abv is surprising.  a good ale, though jolly pumpkins influence on this is not well understood

500 ml bottle from Jonathan Ron Brielle. Poured a deep dark brown with an average sized foamy beige head. The juniper dominates the aroma and the white sage is noticeable, sorry chestnuts maybe next time.  Fuller bodied with average carbonation and a milky coating body that leaves a slight slick on your tongue. Flavor has lots of juniper and pine notes along with some dark bread and light chocolate. One nicely done winter warmer.

Big beige lasting head. Barely translucent dark red body. Herbal floral sage aroma with perfumy minty notes. Initial aroma is awesome, but evaporates quickly. Delicate dry-sweet spicy licorice and chocolate taste with herbal floral notes. Maybe some sage, too. Impressively harmonic given the variety of flavours. Full-bodied. Smooth, hot, faintly oily mouthfeel. Dry aftertaste of what I imagine is sage with coffee notes lingers and then turns bitter. Excellent! Highly sippable. (0.5l bottle, wine monopoly.)

Very deep ambery brown colour, small brown head. Aroma is lots of spices, some nyts, sweet malts as well as some hops. Flavour is caramel malts, spices, some wood and nutttyness. Some mild notes of alcohol is showing as well.

Bottle from Olive Tree Market.  Snagged the last bottle from the shelf!  Pours a deep non translucent brown with a wispy beige head, spotty lacing.  Nice nose of spruce, pine, roasted malts.  Flavor holds some spice, roasted nuts, and a light touch of booze.  I liked this a little better than the original one brewed at Stone.
Dark brown with nice crazy head compliments of mspindler. Aroma sweet brown sugars and a hint of spice. Taste was dark dried fruits and some spices. Pretty good and enjoyable.
bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer.  deep chocolate brown with a cream head. heavy vanilla, spices, nutmeg and some other stuff.  nice on the palate with a spicy vanilla flavor and a smooth finish.

Bottle from Knightly Spirits.  Missed out on last years version.  Pours a very dark brown color with a huge frothy tan head.  Nice foamy retention.  The aroma is interesting, as is everything with this beer; wood, charcoal, berries, dust, lots of spices, alcoholic cleanser.  A lot of spice flavors are featured here and its not at all hard to pick up the sage and juniper berries.  Cinnamon mingles mid palate along with piney hops and ashy notes.  The sage is quite strong at times and lingers in the finish.  This drinks somewhat thin but has more alcohol warmth than I expected.  Slick backing.  A fun one to try and overall pretty solid.

Bottle from Binnys Beverage Depot in Orland Park, Illinois:  This poured a somewhat hazed dark brown body with a very slender tan head that slowly devolves into a film.  The blend of dark malt, sage, juniper, and alcohol delivers quite a medicinal aroma.  The flavor adds a woody, roasty bitterness that makes it more beery and thusly enjoyable.  The finish is a dry mouthful of sage and juniper.  Nice alcohol warmth.

Intense sweet winey, piney, citrus, and fudge with walnuts nose, some nice rum notes too.  Dark blackish brown with deep amber hues, smallish fresh espresso shot head.  Sweet coffee candy, big herbal tangy bitterness.  Small, but poignant carbonation, full body, extremely silky creamy mouth feel, minty bitter, rich finish with late long alcohol warmth.  Excellent beer.  Extremely sophisticated, refined with complex and unique flavors. This beer may have just moved into one of my favorite beers of all time--certainly the best holiday beer.

Pours an opaque very dark brown, black at first glance, with a modest tan head.  Aromas of caramel, chocolate, sage, ginger, alcohol, flowers, and other spice.  Moderately sweet taste with a spicy finish; lightly roasty with flavors of chocolate, fruit, coffee, and spices.  Full bodied, thick velvety texture, and soft carbonation.  Much more stout-like than I was expecting but still very good.  Flavors are all very well integrated and balanced.

Bottle  Pours a good brown with a light tan head.  The head is creamy and lasting.  Leaves fast lacing.  Has a good aroma of ginger, cloves, and oranges.  Has a light carbonation.  The flavor is good.  Light roast, bready, and a touch gin like.  Has a medium body.  The texture is slick like syrup.  Has a good finish and a good aftertaste.  This is unusual but very good.

50cl bottle. Pours murky brown with tight tan head. The aroma is strong with ginger. There are also notes of cloves, cinnamon, and mandarin oranges. The flavor is lightly roasty with soft chocolatey bready fruitcake and strong flavors of ginger. Crystallized ginger with toffee and soft spicy bitterness at mid-palate. The beer finishes dry with cocoa and strong spices. The mouthfeel is crisp and bubbly with a slight chalkiness and a medium-full body. Overall - interesting, but a bit too much ginger.

500 ml bottle poured a clear dark chestnut with a lasting tan head. Aromas of  toffee, carmel, sage, juniper and a hint of nuts. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, toffee, sage, juniper and light nuttiness with a smooth lingering spiced finish.

Bottle Cloudy, dark mahogany ale with a small, creamy, khaki head. Great retention. The nose is very cola-like with standout spices and herbs  juniper berries, sage and caraway are easily identified. Full-bodied with a sticky mouthfeel and modest carbonation. The flavor is sweet cinnamon, brown sugar and winter spices. Finishes sweet and caramelized.

Bottle.  Dark hazy almond brown syrupy pour with very little carbonation and a very alcoholic cloying menthol cherry aroma.  Flavor is much better than the aroma, rich and complex floral flavors are immediately followed by pepper, carameland hops.  Slightly warm on the finish and mellows out nicely.  Decent.

Name: Special Holiday Ale
Date: December 01, 2009
Mode: Bottle
Source: Hop City, Atlanta
Appearance: opaque dark brown, fine beige head, bits of drippy lace
Aroma: sweet and spicy aroma, lots of ginger, minty menthol character
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, lots of spicyness, bright minty ginger, sweet caramel, light bitterness follows the spices
Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.3/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+ /4

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2009 Sage dominates the aroma wafting from the opaque dark amber beer.  Sniffing closer to the creamy white head, the juniper berries peak out from beneath the sage.  The body is creamy with a nutty flavor.  Faint berry towards the end of the sip.  Sage of course is pronounced throughout and intensifies as the beer lingers in my mouth.  Like its predecessor, this was fantastic.

200 bottle.  Pour is nice with a dark chestnut color with brick red highlights and a full, yellowish-canvas-colored, creamy, fluffy head; head retention is good with some nice froth remaining and some soapy lace.  Nose is similar to last year but sweeter and fruiter, which I liked better; still light ginger, lots of eucalyptus/sage notes, toasted caramel, some toffee this year, hints of resins, light chestnuts, and definite berry notes.  Similar flavor as last year but the sweetness not continuing throughout; toffees and berries begin the progression but give way to spicy rye-like notes, toasted grains, light sage, light resins and chestnuts.  Palate is a bit of let down with a smooth and silky texture but not quite medium and nearly soft.  Finishes with minimal sweetness and only less-than-moderate bitterness but notes of sage, light rye spice, faint resins, and lingering chestnuts.  From the start, I thought I would like this one better than last years version from Stone with the Grimstad head and the rich and fruity nose.  But the sweetness diminishes quickly in the flavor and the nice chestnut notes seem to dominate the finish.  The beer is incredibly drinkable, just like last year, which does make for a likable beer but just so dominated by the spices.  Nice offering from three great breweries; I am looking forward to next years at JP.

bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer.  poured murky brown with a white head.  aroma was nutmeg, ginger, cinnamon, and pumpkin.  flavor was pretty much the same as the nose with a light body and a slick feeling.
Sticky X-mas ale that is very much in Belgian style. Not overloaded with spices. It is caramel and toffee. Nutty. Very tasty.

Pour out dark brown black with lots of foam. Smells spicey amost menthol. Taste is fizzy, sticky, Xmas tree. Flavors of pine, nuts, earth, pepper, and mint. Very herbal cough drop. Nice, very interesting holiday  brew.

One of my favorite holiday beers i have ever had. This corroboration brew from three of my favorite brewers is a real treat. The pour is a dark oak. The head is moderate off white hear with decent lacing. The aroma is exactly what you would expect from these breweries combined. It has hints of tartness from jolly pumpkin, fresh fruits from Stone, and delicious malted berries from Nogne O. The flavor is a perfect representation of the aroma. Delicious winter

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2010 500mL. Pours a deep muddy brune to red with a billowing, beige head with good retention but small lace. Aroma of Vicks VapoRub, cinnamon carrots, carrot cake, sour fruits, caramel, white pepper, sage. Taste is sour, tart, slightly spicy, very refreshing, some grape fruit juice. Creamy palate. Very nice.

Bottle. Wow!  First approach reveals an almost minty aroma with a little bit of chocolate. Label reading convinces me that maybe it is juniper and sage, but it had me going there for a second. Body is a leathery dark brown with a decent tan head that continues to rise for a half minute or so after pour is finished. Flavor is about like my initial assessment of the nose: chocolate and mint. It is a little cloying at times, but Ill take it. This is darn nice.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 500ml bottle from total wine in norfolk. pours a dark brown with hints of burgandy and a creamy, light khaki head with great lacing. aroma is great with loads of spices including coriander, nutmeg, spruce, mint leaves, and juniper, hints of dark fruits, nuts, and yams with notes of caramel malts. flavor is excellent as well with savory notes of sage, rosemary, and juniper layered atop toasted rye malts, sweet figs, dried apricots, and hints of carrot cake. palate is medium bodied and creamy with fine carbonation and a nutty, spiced finish. overall, a damn fine holiday ale.
bottle, thanks to ilovedarkbeer, pours  dark brown  with aroma of evergreens, flavors of sweet toffee,  chocolate, somewhat vegetal also

16.9 oz bottle 12/10/09 (Binnys Willowbrook)-Pours a dark brown with a big tan head. Aroma of spices, malt, caramel, and spices. Taste of the same with more sweetness and juniper coming through. This medium bodied brew is well balanced and a little light. It goes down smooth. Nice beer.

This well balanced spiced beer has a fair amount of well balanced nutmeg, clove and coriander. This does not have a very pumkin flavor, but then again so much else is going on that is not a surprise. Overall, a very pleasant and nice beer for the holidays.

drank at cellar temp in 101 bottles in kent ohio. nose is nuts and spicy/tar mix of apricots, pine and black pepper.  flavor is cola and intense dried fruits: strong focused sweetness that turned savory.  sage and juniper leap out of the glass as time goes on and become readily identifiable.  hard to believe such a spice bomb with so much going on could be so drinkable beyond a small sample.
Bottle thanks ti ilovedarkbeer. Hazy gold pour. Aroma is funky, bandaid, and barnyard. Flavor is funky, barnyard and bandaid.

500mL bottle poured into a tulip.

Pours a dark, dark brown out of the bottle and sits almost black in the glass with hints of mahogany around the edges.  There is a tight, thick beige head that shows very good retention and some legs on the sides.

The aroma is dominated by the spices and juniper, with an almost minty character in the nose.  There isnt much of the underlying malts or rye.

The taste is much better and shows a complexity that I think the aroma lacks.  The initial taste is dark roasted malts with the juniper coming out right after.  The finish starts with a smooth spicy rye with some sage as well.

The mouthfeel is on the fuller side of things and extremely smooth with the rye doing its thing.  The carbonation is soft but full of tiny bubbles on the palate.

I think this is a tad better than last years version, though they are certainly very close.  The aroma is a bit spicy for me but the taste is excellent, as is the super creamy mouthfeel.  Creative and tasty.

Dark reddish-brown pour with a healthy light brown head. Aroma of sage, nuts, spices, some medicine. Taste is herbal, spicy, nutty, and sage. Dry smooth drinking. Nice balance of all the flavors. I really enjoyed the aroma of this beer. It was worth the search. The head lasted until the end of the drink. OK lacing, nice aftrtaste. I am glad i purchased two bottles. It will go good with my Christmas dinner.

Bottle from the Coop in Davis, CA. Pours very dark brown with a three-finger tan head. Mixed sage and juniper aromas. And some darkish malt. Full bodied with very frothy/creamy carbonation. For me flavor starts with juniper and stays there. The sage is present, but subdued. The malt kind of isnt there, except for some sweetness. Quite a taste treat.

(Draught at Pikkulintu) Poured almost black with quite large and light brown head. Aroma was very spicy with clove dominating it. Also some salty liquorice could be found. Palate was quite full bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were spiciness, cough mixture, roastedness, hint of chocolate and bitterness. Aftertaste was spicy and bitter.
Pours a nice dark brown color with a decent head. Nose is ludens black cherry menthol cough drops. Taste is chocolate, sage, and winter spices. Enjoyable and warming.
