Deep ruby color, small off-white head. Gingerbread aroma, also malty, slightly alcoholic, some licorice. Balanced maltyness. Xmasy spices: ginger, clove, then some caramel and light alcohol. Some hops in the aftertaste. Very drinkable Christmas beer.
Bottle. A very interesting brew. Aroma had a strong note of the Sage and Juniper Berries. The Chestnuts werent as present as I would expect. Pretty thick.

Bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer. Quite different from the Stone version (and looking forward to the Jolly Pumpkin version!!!) . Pours with a tan head and a deep brown body. Aroma of currant, safe, thyme, turkey stuffing, chestnut and maple. Taste is bitter (hoppy) with chestnut, sage and maple. Thick with medium to light bubbles. Bigger and sweeter than the Stone version.

Bottle from tarheel wine in Youngsville, NC.  Bright cloudy pour with a fluffy white head.  SPicy aroma.  Nuts, grains, floral notes, and light spice from the juniper berries.  Far from worth the $9 price tag

Bottle shared at the DC Local tasting.  Pours a translucent, nearly opaque nut brown with a frothy, active, lasting tan head.  Aroma is heavy on fruits, spices, ginger, cloves, anise, oranges, juniper.  Flavor is sweet, a little smokey, oranges, berries.  Sweet, sticky finish.  A lot going on in this one.

50cl bottle.  Medium tan head atop hazy red-brown body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, allspice, some juniper, light yeast, faint metallic.  Taste is sweet, caramel, some chocolate, allspice, cranberry, light alcohol, metallic.  Medium body, light effervescence despite low carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2010 Bottle split with Dallas. Pours a dark coca-cola body with great off-white lacing.  The aroma is definitely characteristic of both Nogne and JP - the sharp roastiness common with Nognes darker brews and the slight tartness akin to most JP brews. The mouth feel of this one is great, perfectly balanced and well carbonated. The flavors hit the tongue with a nice complexity - notes of spice, vegies, tart, and sweet roasty malt. Hands down best beer to get blacked out with Santa.

Shared with jredmond. Pours a cola brown with little head. Smells of vegetables, spice, and faint tartness. Tastes of spices, vegetables, and a malty, roasted aftertaste. Incredible mouthfeel. Finishes smooth, sweet and neat. Great christmas brew.

This beer is intriguing.  It pours deep brown with a quickly dissipating head. On first sniff the aroma is minty, which is slightly strange but fitting for Christmas.   Theres spruce, cardamon, honey, chocolate and possibly some nutmeg in there, too.  The taste at first is bewildering, but after the initial realization that its an extremely unusual beer, the glass is hard to put down.  Taste is primarily cardamon, but also a bit of menthol, some alcohol, bitter chocolate, and grapefruit hop.  The taste keeps changing and the flavor lingers.

Bottle. Chocolate-brown pour with a medium, smooth, off-white head with good lacing. Aromas of menthol, black licorice, and ginger. Sage, camphor, cardamom, cigar tobacco, eucalyptus, and tight berry flavors lead to piney hops and a spicy finish.

Pours very dark brown/black with light at the edges and a thin brown head. Aroma is dominated by the spices in the beer with hints of malt and a little nuttiness. Flavor is rich malt, nuttiness, bits of roast malt, chocolate, and smoke. Then the spices start to take over the long finish. Very complex with alcohol well hidden.

Bottle shared by argo0: Pours a mostly opaque black with dark mahogany edges and a smooth creamy beige head.  Aroma of sweet dark caramel malts with some herbal fruity plums and berries.  Starts with a rich full caramel malty sweetness with lots of effervescent carbonation and fruity berry complexity before a slightly smoky chocolate finish with some grapefruity flavor hops.  A well-balanced and unique holiday brew.

Pours a deep umber copper with a thin one finger yellowish tan head. Nose is rich and spicy, sweet spice, bready, juniper, caramel. Flavor shows a nutmeg character, juniper, sweet malt, meaty, well integrated. Palate shows a medium carbonation with a nice viscosity and well contained spice presence.

Thanks 17thfloor! Pours a deep brown with a small light tan head. Aroma is heavily spiced, some coffee, cola, cardamom and dark fruits abound. A smorgashboard of aromas. Flavor starts thick and heavy on the palate, tons of berry that is balanced by the coffee and some chocolate and is still loaded with spices. There is a ton of stuff going on and its a matter of separating and appreciating each aspect, which proved to be tough at times. Medium to full rich body and a nice carbonation. Very interesting beer, different but unique

Pours a darker but translucent tootsie-roll color with a fine fizzy off-white head.  Aroma is very similar to last years, seeming lots of cardamom, juniper, urinal cake, sweet and spicy, rich malty notes but covered up by all the spices.  Wow, flavor is completely different, smokey/leather with huge amounts of juniper berries, most juniper Ive ever tasted, lots of chocolate, medicinal, spruce, I like this much better than last years, smoother and more cohesive.   Great body, medium full, rich without being syrupy, fantastic carbonation, big and lively fluffy and not at all annoying.  Wow, I cant belive I actually like this.

Dark chestnut brown pour with tan, creamy head that settles down to a film.   Aroma of spruce, menthol, nutella.  Flavor is like eating eating a nutella and vicks vapor rub sandwich.  Maybe some trees and grass in there as well.  Cant wait for the jolly pumpkin version, because this brewery is so over rated.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2011 Jan 2011: Bottle (50cl) from Vinmonopolet (Rosenkrantz gate), Oslo. Batch 528 (BB 5.8.2015). Very dark (almost opaque) brown colour with a red hue. Large beige head, settles as a stable ring and film with a small amount of lacing. Somewhat restrained nose of cloves (predominantly), menthol, licorice, cardamom, malt. Taste is more balanced (cloves more subdued), quite sweet with a nice hop bitterness that dominates the aftertaste (along with some smoked wood and medicinal elements). Mouthfeel is soft and creamy, medium/full body. Highly drinkable.
Nov 2009: On tap at Olympen, Oslo. Dark brown colour. Astonishing menthol/medicinal aroma - certainly peculiar. Rich taste of menthol, forest fruits, licquorice, malts. Quite, but not overly, medicinal - its as if a shot of bitter liqueur has been admixed. It shares some of the rawness of the Imperial Wit of the same brewery. Not something I could drink two of in a row, but I found it highly enjoyable after the initial bewilderment. Rating 3.5 (6, 3, 7, 4, 15).

Bottle.Pours a Christmas-Eve-in-Scandanavia-at-midnight-black with an aroma of mentholated berry cough drops and sugary cherry.  Flavor is medicinal hops (cough syrup, cherry menthol) with a thick medicinal berry finish.  Average and slightly tingly on the tongue.  Interesting.  Should be better than it is but as it stands, its way too mediciny.  Might benefit from some aging to quell the medicine factor.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Aroma of figs, liquorish, sweet malt, esters, and alcohol.  Pours a very very dark brown or black.  With a light tan head.  Taste is nice boozey and sweet. Like a lot of spices, dark fruits, and really nice yeast and water.  Well made winter beer, wish i could have this every night this winter.

Bottle from Sams.  Surprised at how much I liked this.  Poured dark brown with big-bubbled beige head.  Nose very spicy and juniper-y, but the complexity of it came out after sipping awhile, and I didnt find it overwhelming.  All the elements described on the bottle were there, but more malty sweetness on the palate.  Good deal of cocoa there, too. Great after-dinner beer consumed with pumpkin cookies the night before Thanksgiving.

Pours a dark brown with a cream-colored head.  Good lacing.  Aroma of spice, chestnuts, and fruit.  Super creamy mouth feel.  On the palate spice dominates with chestnut, fruit, and caramel.  Very different and very good!

A 500ml Nogne bottle.  Pour is deep rich brown with a nice light bown head.  Aroma is light malt, a bit more hops than expected, lightly herbal, and a touch of mocha.  The flavor is initially nice rich caramel malt.  Also notes of coffee, a nice balancing hop character, faint cocoa nibs, subtle dark fruits, and a pleasant bitter-sweet finish. The slight bitterness of the chestnuts really help to create a crisp finish that balances out the sweet malt and keeps you comming back for more. This is a very nice beer; extremely well balnced and quite easy to drink.  Sad to say it was the only one left on the shelf.  Maybe more will pop up.

Pours a deep hazelnut brown with a small tan lace that remains.  Nose of whit sage, juniper berries, some barrel/ wood and cola.  Flavor and mouthfeel of an alcoholic soda with a little less carbonation.  More juniper, sage, lots of sweetness, almost unbearable after a few sips.

Sampled from bottle at a blind-tasting session. An opaque,  dark brown body, under a foamy, two-finger latte head. Toasted, peppery dark malts and  loads of Christmas-spices to the nose. Some ashy notes and a whiff of  plums, sour berries and beef-stock. Taste is slightly sweet, with a medium malt body, lightly roasted, peppery, with a hint of smoky sourness. The Christmas-spices is well prononced in the flavor as well, but never overdone. A good amount of earthy bittering hops underneath. Also licorice notes, and a distinct plummy and berry-ish fruitiness. Medium body strenght. Feels clean and light in the mouth, despite the complexity. Rounded, spicy, malty and gently bitter ending.

bottle.  a deep brown/black under a medium sized, creamy beige head.  minty herbal aroma. medium bodied with moderate carbonation.  flavor is also very herbal and minty with sage, mint, wintergreen.  also some caramel malts.  this is more herbal than i remember the 2008 version being.  the berry flavor develops as it warms and the spices mellow a bit.  the alcohol is hidden.  i liked it better at room temp.

Bottled at Stocholm Beer Festival.  Cloudy amber, small creamy head. Aroma of cinnamon and nutmeg. Sweet and full bodied, piney with notes of almond. Dried out by hops that also give marked bitterness.

500ml Bottle:  Aroma of sage, juniper, spices, hops, slight ginger, slight malts, light nutmeg, and slight nuts.  Poured brown in color with a small, loose, brown head that disappeared quickly.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of small, medium, and large-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of spices, nutmeg, sage, light juniper, light malts, slight cocoa, and a hint of nuts.  Medium body.  Lightly tingly texture.  Average carbonation.  Spice, nutmeg, sage, and slight malt finish is slightly dry.  8.5%ABV is completely hidden.

500 ml bottle. Pours dark brown with a big creamy tan head, long duration. Aroma of spicy dark malts, dust and tar.Strong malty taste,sweet caramel, liquorice, some bitterness towards the end, makes this a perfect find for long dark evenings

Bottle. Poured a medium and cloudy brown color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of spices with some caramel, and toasted nuttiness. Tastes of of the same. Definitely a spice beer for sure.

Lightly hazy brown color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of lots of spices, sage, ginger, and juniper, with nuts, caramel malts, and light roasted malts.  Taste of caramel malts, juniper berries, ginger, nuts, cinnamon, and brown sugar.  Thanks to hopdog for this one!

Thanks to ericgizits or was it hopdiggitydog?... for picking this one up. Pours a hazy brownish chestnut with a bubbly off white head. Aroma of nutmeg, ginger, licorice, cherries, cinnamon, brown sugar and toasted malt.  Flavor of the same spice mix but more toned down.  Great holiday ale.

50cl bottle from Vinmonopolet. Batch 440. Brewed 2009-07-27. Best before 2014-07-27. It poured a a dark brown colour with a huge beige creamy head that settled down slowly in the glass. The aroma is very reminiscent of God Jul (Winter Ale) and some parts of Underlig Jul (Peculiar Yule). Notes of spices, liquorice, roasted malts and dark coffee. Some dark caramel or toffee as well. The flavour is sweet and just a tad bitter. Notes of roasted malts, spices, caramel and coffee. It has a medium long aftertaste. A very nice sipping-beer for christmas.

500 ml bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. Dark mahogany coloured beer, huge beige creamy head with good retention. Lovely aroma of Christmas spices, anise and English liquorice. Extremely rich mouthfeel. Powerful malty sweetness in the flavour, with an abundancy of Christmas spices, anise and English liquorice. Hints of juniper berries and burnt caramel. Lots of liquorice in the long aftertaste.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet.
Lots of soft fruit, sweet oranges. Sweet, full malty base for the spices.
I found the sage most prominent on the palate, but it all blends wonderfully together. Lots of nuances, this is for slow sipping.
